page.title: List of musical works in unusual time signatures

revision.comment: Undid revision 870688955 by [[Special:Contributions/137.44.141.196|137.44.141.196]] ([[User talk:137.44.141.196|talk]]) 3+3+3 is not unusual
revision.text:
{{Dynamic list}}{{citations broken|date=March 2017}} <!--**********************************************************************************************
BEFORE YOU ADD ANY NEW PIECES, PLEASE MAKE SURE YOU CITE A RELIABLE SOURCE! TRYING TO INTERPRET THE RHYTHM YOURSELF, NO MATTER HOW SURE YOU ARE, COUNTS AS ORIGINAL RESEARCH! (see [[WP:OR]]) IF YOU WISH TO CITE A SOURCE, PLEASE SEE [[WP:CITE]] – ANY UNSOURCED ADDITIONS WILL BE REMOVED! DO NOT USE ANOTHER WIKIPEDIA PAGE AS A SOURCE EITHER!
Please list unsourced material on the Unsourced list linked on the Talk Page. It is a good resource for people who are confident enough to count for themselves.
*************************************************************************************************-->This is a list of [[musical composition]]s or [[Musical piece|piece]]s of music that have [[unusual time signatures]]. "Unusual" is here defined to be any time signature other than simple time signatures with top numerals of 2, 3, or 4 and bottom numerals of 2, 4, or 8, and compound time signatures with top numerals of 6, 9, or 12 and bottom numerals 4, 8, or 16.<ref name="musictechmag">Ian Waugh first lists {{music|time|2|2}}, {{music|time|2|4}}, {{music|time|2|8}}, {{music|time|3|2}}, {{music|time|3|4}}, {{music|time|3|8}}, {{music|time|4|2}}, {{music|time|4|4}}, {{music|time|4|8}}, {{music|time|6|4}}, {{music|time|6|8}}, {{music|time|6|16}}, {{music|time|9|4}}, {{music|time|9|8}}, {{music|time|9|16}}, {{music|time|12|4}}, {{music|time|12|8}}, and {{music|time|12|16}} (Waugh 2003, 76), then says "we've listed all the popular time signatures" (Waugh 2003, 77).</ref>
The conventions of musical notation typically allow for more than one written representation of a particular piece. The chosen time signature largely depends upon musical context, personal taste of the composer or transcriber, and the graphic layout on the written page. Frequently, published editions were written in a specific time signature to visually signify the tempo for slow movements in symphonies, sonatas, and concerti.
A perfectly consistent unusual metrical pattern may be notated in a more familiar time signature that does not correspond to it. For example, the Passacaglia from [[Benjamin Britten|Britten's]] opera ''[[Peter Grimes]]'' consists of variations over a recurring bass line eleven beats in length but is notated in ordinary {{music|time|4|4}} time, with each variation lasting {{frac|2|3|4}} bars, and therefore commencing each time one crotchet earlier in the bar than the preceding one had done.<ref>Britten 1945b.</ref> {{TOC limit|2}}
== Upper number of 1 ==
=== {{music|time|1|1}} ===
*''[[Enigma Variations]]'' by [[Edward Elgar]]. Variation VII is in ''Presto'' {{music|time|1|1}}.<ref>[http://genedelisa.com/2010/05/elgar-enigma-variations/]</ref> *[[Symphony No. 2 (Borodin)|Symphony No. 2]] by [[Alexander Borodin]]. Movement II is in ''Prestissimo'' {{music|time|1|1}}, except for the [[ternary form|trio]] section, which is in ''Allegretto'' {{music|time|6|4}}.<ref>Borodin [8888], 44–86.</ref>
=== {{music|time|1|2}} ===
*''[[Appalachian Spring]]'', by [[Aaron Copland]]. Third bar of rehearsal 46 and third bar of rehearsal 48 are in {{music|time|1|2}}.<ref>Copland 1945, 56–59.</ref> *[[Decet (Enescu)|''Decet'']] for wind instruments, Op. 14, by [[George Enescu]]. Movement III, Bar 240 (fifth bar before rehearsal number 42) is in {{music|time|1|2}}.<ref>Enescu 1965, 62.</ref> *''Fünf Klavierstücke'', Op. 23 by [[Arnold Schoenberg]]. Movement II, bar 9 is in {{music|time|1|2}}.<ref>http://petruccilibrary.ca/download.php?file=files/imglnks/caimg/0/03/IMSLP00782-Schoenberg_op23_No2.pdf</ref> *''[[Káťa Kabanová]]'', by [[Leoš Janáček]]. Act III contains some {{music|time|1|2}} bars between rehearsal numbers 5 and 8.<ref name="Kabanova3">http://conquest.imslp.info/files/imglnks/usimg/8/8e/IMSLP58460-PMLP119865-Janáček_-_Káťa_Kabanová_-_Act_III_(vocal_score).pdf</ref> *''La Langeur'', from ''Le follie francaise ou les dominos'' from ''[[Pieces de Clavecin]]'' by [[Francois Couperin]].<ref>http://cnks.imslp.org/files/imglnks/usimg/4/46/IMSLP99159-PMLP200270-Couperin_-_Pieces_de_clavecin_Bk3.pdf</ref> * Nocturne No. 1 by [[Francis Poulenc]], from ''8 Nocturnes'', FP 56. Bar 27 is in {{music|time|1|2}}.<ref name=":0">http://petruccilibrary.ca/download.php?file=files/imglnks/caimg/7/7b/IMSLP309054-PMLP499658-Poulenc_-_Huit_Nocturnes__piano_.pdf</ref> *[[Piano Sonata No. 5 (Scriabin)|Piano Sonata No. 5]], Op. 53, by [[Alexander Scriabin]]. Bars 251 to 262 (''Presto giocoso'') are in {{music|time|1|2}}.<ref>{{IMSLP2|work=Piano Sonata No.5, Op.53 (Scriabin, Aleksandr)|cname=Piano Sonata No. 5 (Scriabin)}}. Leipzig: Edition Peters, 1971, plate E.P. 12588.</ref> *''Quartet'', Op. 22, by [[Anton Webern]]. In the second movement, bars 1–3, 5–6, 8–10, 12–14, 16–129, and 131–191 are in {{music|time|1|2}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://imslp.eu/files/imglnks/euimg/1/11/IMSLP28222-PMLP61954-Webern_-_Quartet__Op._22.pdf|title=Archived copy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160910092556/http://imslp.eu/Files/imglnks/euimg/1/11/IMSLP28222-PMLP61954-Webern_-_Quartet__Op._22.pdf|archivedate=2016-09-10|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2017-03-26|df=}}</ref> *''[[Rapsodie negre]]'' by [[Francis Poulenc]], third movement, "Honoloulou", contains some bars of {{music|time|1|2}}.<ref>https://imslp.org/wiki/Special:ImagefromIndex/309641/pasw {{Full|date=July 2018}}<!--This links to what appears to be a set of parts for flute, clarinet, string quartet, and baritone voice. Publisher, place of publication, year, and a page citation for the bars in question are needed.--></ref> *[[String Quartet No. 1 (Bartók)|String Quartet No. 1]], by [[Béla Bartók]]. Bars 3, 10, and 22 of the third movement are in {{music|time|1|2}}.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xaQvPhVvQaY</ref> *[[Symphony No. 1 (Elgar)|Symphony No. 1]], by [[Edward Elgar]]. Second movement, entirely in {{music|time|1|2}}.<ref>Edward Elgar, [http://conquest.imslp.info/files/imglnks/usimg/8/89/IMSLP56155-PMLP39959-Elgar_-_Symphony_No._1,_Op._55_(orch._score).pdf Symphony No. 1] (London: Eulenberg Edition, n.d.), 62–101.</ref> *Symphony No. 17 in G{{music|sharp}} minor by [[Nikolay Myaskovsky]]. Movement I has a {{music|time|1|2}} signature from rehearsal numbers 2–7, 25–35, 42–47, 59–66, and 70–74.<ref>Myaskovsky 1947, 4–8, 23–30, 41–44, 59–65, 70–73.</ref>
=== {{music|time|1|4}} ===
*''[[Alcancías]]'' by [[Silvestre Revueltas]]. Movement II, 5 bars after rehearsal 24, second bar of rehearsal 27, first bar of rehearsal 28, third bar of rehearsal 29, one bar before 31, and one bar before 32 are all {{music|time|1|4}}.<ref>Revueltas 1971, 32, 34–38.</ref> * "The Eynsham Poacher", a traditional song; in the arrangement by [[Dave Pegg]], most of the tune is in {{music|time|12|8}}, but the finale includes one bar of {{music|time|1|4}}.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Fairport Convention Songbook 2 |editor-last=Allcock |editor-first=Maartin |publisher=Woodworm Music |year=1998 |pages=56–59 }}</ref> *''Mädchentotenlieder'', by [[Bo Nilsson]]. Bars 20, 22–27, 33–36, 38–40, 43, 49, 51, 54, 57, 65, 76–77, 80–81, 86, 90–93, 95, 99, 103–7, 115–16, 118, 120, 122, 124, 126, 130, 134–42, 145, 153, and 158 are in {{music|time|1|4}} time.<ref name=":1">Nilsson 1958, 3–15.</ref> *''[[Metastaseis (Xenakis)|Metastaseis]]'', by [[Iannis Xenakis]]. The first 103 bars are in {{music|time|1|4}}.<ref>https://monoskop.org/images/4/48/Xenakis_Iannis_Metastaseis_B_1953-54_score.pdf</ref> *''Metropolis Part 1: The Miracle and the Sleeper'', by [[Dream Theater]]. Third bar of rehearsal R is in {{music|time|1|4}}.<ref>Dream Theater Keyboard Anthology. Transcribed by Chris Romero and Jordan Baker 2004, 30.</ref> *''[[On an Overgrown Path]]'', by [[Leoš Janáček]]. There are isolated {{music|time|1|4}} bars in the sixth, tenth, and eleventh movements.<ref name=":2">http://ks.imslp.net/files/imglnks/usimg/5/50/IMSLP09955-Janacek20On20an20overgrown20path.pdf</ref> *''[[Petrushka (ballet)|Petrushka]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]], the bar before rehearsal 17 is in {{music|time|1|4}}.<ref>Stravinsky n.d., 26.</ref> *[[Piano Sonata No. 3 (Chávez)|Piano Sonata No. 3]] by [[Carlos Chávez]]. Movement I, bars 13, 15, 19, 52, 54, and 58 are in {{music|time|1|4}} time.<ref>Chávez 1972, 3–4.</ref>
=== {{music|time|1|8}} ===
*''[[Lincolnshire Posy]]'' by [[Percy Grainger]]. Movement V, "Lord Melbourne", uses {{music|time|1|8}}.<ref name="imslp.org">{{cite web|url=http://imslp.org/wiki/Lincolnshire_Posy_(Grainger,_Percy)|title=Lincolnshire Posy (Grainger, Percy) – IMSLP/Petrucci Music Library: Free Public Domain Sheet Music|publisher=}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=August 2016}}<!--The linked page says nothing about any meter signatures.--> *''Mädchentotenlieder'', by [[Bo Nilsson]]. Bar 11 is in {{music|time|1|16}} time, bar 53 is in {{music|time|1|8}} time.<ref name=":1" /> *''A Nightmare to Remember'', by [[Dream Theater]]. Measure 31 is in {{music|time|1|8}}.<ref>Dream Theater Black Clouds and Silver Linings Authentic Guitar TAB. 2009, 7.</ref> *''[[On an Overgrown Path]]'', by [[Leoš Janáček]]. There are two {{music|time|1|8}} bars in the third movement.<ref name=":2" /> *[[Piano Sonata No. 3 (Chávez)|Piano Sonata No. 3]] by [[Carlos Chávez]]. Movement II, bar 176 is in {{music|time|1|8}} time.<ref>Chávez 1972, 12.</ref> *''[[A próle do bébé]]'', Book 2 by [[Heitor Villa-Lobos]]. The fifth piece, "O Cavalinho de páu" (The Little Wooden Horse), bar 68 is in {{music|time|2|[4]}}{{music|time|1|8}} time.<ref>Villa-Lobos 1927, 5:4.</ref>
=== {{music|time|1|16}} ===
*''Mädchentotenlieder'', by [[Bo Nilsson]]. Bar 11 is in {{music|time|1|16}} time.<ref name=":1" /> *''The Mirror'', by [[Dream Theater]]. In {{music|time|1|16}}.<ref>https://tabs.ultimate-guitar.com/tab/dream_theater/the_mirror_tabs_125540.</ref>
=== {{music|time|1|64}} ===
*"A Headache And A Sixty-Fourth", from [[Ron Jarzombek]]'s album ''[[Solitarily Speaking Of Theoretical Confinement|Solitarily Speaking of Theoretical Confinement]]'', has a constant time signature pattern of {{music|time|4|4}} and {{music|time|1|64}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ronjarzombek.com/headache.html|title=A Headache And A Sixty-Fourth|accessdate=2010-08-21}}</ref>
== Upper number of 2 ==
==={{music|time|2|1}}===
*''Five Pieces for Piano'', op. 23, by [[Arnold Schoenberg]].<ref name="Read158">Read 1964, 158.</ref> *''[[Káťa Kabanová]]'', by [[Leoš Janáček]]. Act II is in {{music|time|2|1}} from rehearsal number 20 to just before rehearsal number 24; act III is in {{music|time|2|1}} for four bars before rehearsal number 27 and six bars before rehearsal number 28, followed by a mixture of {{music|time|2|1}} and {{music|cut-time}} between rehearsal numbers 28 and 29, and one bar before rehearsal number 36.<ref name="Kabanova3" /><ref>http://conquest.imslp.info/files/imglnks/usimg/5/5b/IMSLP58459-PMLP119865-Janáček_-_Káťa_Kabanová_-_Act_II_(vocal_score).pdf</ref> *[[Partita for keyboard No. 6 (Bach)|Partita No. 6 in E minor, BWV 830]], by [[Johann Sebastian Bach]]. The last movement, a [[gigue]], is in {{music|time|2|1}} in the Bischoff edition; however, the symbol [[File:Tempus perf prol min dim.svg|x22px]] (the [[Time signature#Mensural time signatures|mensuration sign]] for "tempus perfectum, prolatio minor, diminutum") appears in the first edition of 1731, and {{music|cut-time}} = {{music|time|2|2}} in the autograph manuscript).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bachcellonotes.blogspot.com/2016/02/how-do-we-play-gigue-of-partita-no6.html|title=Bach's Cello Suites, Editor's Notes: How do we play the Gigue of Partita No.6 ?|last=Yokoyama|first=Shin-itchiro|date=21 February 2016|publisher=}}</ref> This time signature is unusual for gigues, which are usually in {{music|time|6|8}} or {{music|time|12|8}}.<ref>http://ks.imslp.net/files/imglnks/usimg/e/e3/IMSLP414162-PMLP667919-Bach_Partita_No_6_Gigue_Comparison.pdf</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_M8RUaKmwYAC&pg=PT84|title=Six Partitas and Overture in French Style|author=Johann Bach|publisher=Alfred Music Publishing|year=1985|isbn=978-0-7692-8604-4|editor=Hans Bischoff|page=92}}</ref> *''[[Pli selon pli]]'' by [[Pierre Boulez]]. Movement III, "Improvisation II sur Mallarmé".<ref name="Read158" />
==={{music|time|2|16}}===
* ''[[Comme le vent]]'', first of the ''Douze études dans toutes les tons mineurs'', Op. 39, by [[Charles-Valentin Alkan]].<ref>Alkan n.d. (ca.1861),{{Page needed|date=June 2013}}<!--Only of marginal importance, considering the nature of the publication, but for the sake of consistency with other references.-->.</ref>
*''[[The Rite of Spring]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]]. {{music|time|2|16}} is used in the concluding "Sacrificial Dance".<ref name="rite" /> :<score vorbis="1"> { \new PianoStaff << \new Staff \relative c'' { \set Staff.midiInstrument = #"violin" \clef treble \tempo 8 = 126 \time 3/16 r16 <d c a fis d>\f-! r16\fermata | \time 2/16 r <d c a fis d>-! \time 3/16 r <d c a fis d>8-! | r16 <d c a fis d>8-! | \time 2/8 <d c a fis>16-! <e c bes g>->-![ <cis b aes f>-! <c a fis ees>-!] } \new Staff \relative c { \set Staff.midiInstrument = #"violin" \clef bass \time 3/16 d,16-! <bes'' ees,>-! r\fermata | \time 2/16 <d,, d,>-! <bes'' ees,>-! | \time 3/16 d16-! <ees cis>8-! | r16 <ees cis>8-! | \time 2/8 d16\sf-! <ees cis>-!->[ <d c>-! <d c>-!] } >> } </score>
* ''Sketch'', Op. 1 No. 10, by [[Alexei Stanchinsky]].<ref name="stanchinskyop1">http://petrucci.mus.auth.gr/imglnks/usimg/f/f3/IMSLP14991-Stanchinksy_-_12_Sketches.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://imslp.org/wiki/Category:Stanchinsky,_Alexei|title=Category:Stanchinsky, Aleksey|publisher=|accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref>
== Upper number of 3 == {{seealso|Triple meter}} ==={{music|time|3|1}}=== * "[[O Fortuna]]" from [[Carl Orff]]'s ''[[Carmina Burana (Orff)|Carmina Burana]]'' (first four bars).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5owPoSSOa94|title=1.- O Fortuna (Carmina Burana – C. Orff) Score Animation|last=Score'sAnimation|first=|date=7 October 2015|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> *[[Symphony No. 3 (Saint-Saëns)|Symphony No. 3]] by [[Camille Saint-Saëns]], in two sections (a total of 21 bars) at the end of the finale.<ref>http://ks.imslp.info/files/imglnks/usimg/1/1c/IMSLP29121-PMLP50421-Saint-Saens_-_Symphony_No_3_in_c_Op_78_-_2.pdf</ref> * "Um Mitternacht" by [[Gustav Mahler]] (''Rückert Lieder'' No. 5). Bar 27 is marked "{{music|time|6|2}} ({{music|time|3|1}})".<ref>See any of the scores available on https://imslp.org/wiki/R%C3%BCckert_Lieder_(Mahler%2C_Gustav). Bar 27 is at rehearsal number 4.</ref>
==={{music|time|3|16}}===
*[[Piano Sonata No. 1 (Brahms)|Piano Sonata No. 1 in C major, Op. 1]], by [[Johannes Brahms]]. Movement II, bars 47–49 and 51–53.<ref name="BrahmsOp1" /> *''[[The Rite of Spring]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]]. {{music|time|3|16}} is used in the concluding "Sacrificial Dance".<ref name="rite" /> *[[String Quartet (Webern)|String Quartet, Op. 28]], by [[Anton Webern]]. Movement III is in {{music|time|3|16}} from bars 40 to 41, and again from bars 44 to 51.<ref name="Webern" /> *[[Symphonic Studies (Schumann)|''Symphonic Studies'']], Étude IX (first version) by [[Robert Schumann]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304093701/http://conquest.imslp.info/files/imglnks/usimg/9/91/IMSLP289811-PMLP02189-Schumann__Robert_Werke_Breitkopf_Gregg_Serie_7_Band_2_RS_51_Op_13_scan.pdf]</ref> * [[Variations for piano (Webern)|Variations for piano]], Op. 27, by [[Anton Webern]], movement I.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://imslp.eu/Files/imglnks/euimg/4/4d/IMSLP28271-PMLP04634-Webern_-_Variations__Op._27.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-06-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509153731/http://imslp.eu/Files/imglnks/euimg/4/4d/IMSLP28271-PMLP04634-Webern_-_Variations__Op._27.pdf |archivedate=2016-05-09 |df= }}</ref>
==={{music|time|3|32}}=== *''Intrada, nebst burlesquer Suite'', for two violins (the so-called "Gulliver Suite") by [[Georg Philipp Telemann]]. Movement II, "Lilliputsche Chaconne".<ref>Telemann 1728, 32; Telemann 1970, 13; Zohn 2004, 247: "The ‘Lilliputsche Chaconne’ is anything but stately as it flashes by (at least on the page) in a blur of demisemiquavers in {{music|time|3|32}} time. . . ."</ref> *''[[Pribaoutki]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]]. The fourth piece, "Starets i zayats", uses {{music|time|3|32}} in bar 15.<ref name="pribaoutki">http://petruccilibrary.us/Scores/scores/Stravinsky_Igor_1971/Stravinsky_-_Pribaoutki_FullScore.pdf</ref> *[[String Quartet (Webern)|String Quartet]], Op. 28, by [[Anton Webern]]: the third movement is in {{music|time|3|32}} from bars 28 to 37.<ref name="Webern">{{cite web |url=http://imslp.eu/Files/imglnks/euimg/7/70/IMSLP28223-PMLP61956-Webern_-_String_Quartet__Op._28__score_.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-06-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808091650/http://imslp.eu/Files/imglnks/euimg/7/70/IMSLP28223-PMLP61956-Webern_-_String_Quartet__Op._28__score_.pdf |archivedate=2016-08-08 |df= }}</ref>
== Upper number of 4 ==
=== {{music|time|4|16}} === <!--NB: 4/16 qualifies as an unusual time signature by the definition given in the lede, that only signatures with "top numerals of 2, 3, or 4 and bottom numerals of 2, 4, or 8" are usual. The bottom numeral here falls outside the definition.--> *''[[Homenaje a Federico García Lorca]]'' by [[Silvestre Revueltas]]. Movement I, "Baile" (Dance), is entirely in {{music|time|4|16}}, except for one [[Free time (music)|free-rhythm]] bar at the beginning and two at the end.<ref>Revueltas 1958, 3–15.</ref> *[[Piano Sonata No. 1 (Brahms)|Piano Sonata No. 1 in C major, Op. 1]], by [[Johannes Brahms]]. Movement II, bars 46 and 50.<ref name="BrahmsOp1">http://hz.imslp.info/files/imglnks/usimg/4/40/IMSLP06091-Brahms_-_Piano_Sonata_No.1_-_Sauer.pdf</ref> *[[Piano Sonata No. 3 (Brahms)|Piano Sonata No. 3 in F minor, Op. 5]], by [[Johannes Brahms]]. Movement II, bars 37–66 and 77–90.<ref>[http://imslp.nl/imglnks/usimg/f/f2/IMSLP06093-Brahms_-_Piano_Sonata_No.3_-_Sauer.pdf Brahms 1928], 78–79, 79–80.</ref> *''[[Pribaoutki]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]]. The fourth piece, "Starets i zayats", uses {{music|time|4|16}} in bar 16.<ref name="pribaoutki" /> *''[[The Rite of Spring]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]]. {{music|time|4|16}} is used in the concluding "Sacrificial Dance".<ref name="rite" /> *[[String Quartet (Webern)|String Quartet]], Op. 28, by [[Anton Webern]]: the third movement is in {{music|time|4|16}} from bars 52 to 53.<ref name="Webern" /> *''Variations on a Theme by Robert Schumann'', Op. 9, by [[Johannes Brahms]]. Variation XI.<ref>https://imslp.nl/imglnks/usimg/2/2a/IMSLP08431-Brahms_-_Variations_Op.9_-_Sauer.pdf</ref>
== Upper number of 5 == <!--Add new pieces to the list at [[Quintuple meter]].--> {{main|Quintuple meter}}
== Upper number of 6 == {{seealso|Sextuple meter}}
=== {{music|time|6|2}} === * "Um Mitternacht" by [[Gustav Mahler]] (''Rückert Lieder'' No. 5). Bar 27 is marked "{{music|time|6|2}} ({{music|time|3|1}})".<ref>See any of the scores available on https://imslp.org/wiki/R%C3%BCckert_Lieder_(Mahler%2C_Gustav). Bar 27 is at rehearsal number 4.</ref>
== Upper number of 7 == <!--Add new pieces to the list at [[Septuple meter]].--> {{main|Septuple meter}}
== Upper number of 8 ==
:''Note:'' {{music|time|8|4}} ''or'' {{music|time|8|8}} ''may refer to an evenly divided compound duple or quadruple meter. While this is arguably extremely common in music, the notations ''{{music|time|8|4}}'' and ''{{music|time|8|8}}'' themselves are not, so all divisions of this time signature are listed here''
==={{music|time|8|4}}===
*[[A Choral Fantasia (Holst)|''A Choral Fantasia'', op. 51]], by [[Gustav Holst]]. Bars 36–69, 142–48, 173–78, and 191–98 are in {{music|time|8|4}}.<ref>Holst 1977, 4–6, 18–19, 23–24, 27–30.</ref> *"[[All You Need Is Love]]" by [[The Beatles]]. The main verse pattern contains a total of 29 [[beat (music)|beat]]s, split into two {{music|time|7|4}} measures, a single bar of {{music|time|8|4}}, followed by a one bar return of {{music|time|7|4}} before repeating the pattern.<ref>Dean 2014.</ref> *"Damage Control" by [[John Petrucci]] has several bars in {{music|time|8|4}}.<ref>Suspended Animation Authentic Guitar TAB, transcribed by Jordan Baker. 2005, 81–85, 88–89, 105–107</ref> * "[[I Ejaculate Fire]]" by [[Dethklok]]. Bars 81, 83, 85, and 88 are in {{music|time|8|4}}.<ref>Dethalbum III Authentic Guitar TAB, transcribed by Jordan Baker. 2013, 10{{Full|date=August 2013}}<!--Place and publisher needed, if this is a print publication; URL needed if it is published online.--></ref> *''[[Musica ricercata]]'' for piano, by [[György Ligeti]], movement 2 (Mesto, rigido e cerimoniale) includes a single bar of {{music|time|8|4}}.{{sfn|Ligeti|1995|loc=9, b. 28}} *''[[The Rite of Spring]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]], in the tableau "Mysterious Games of the Maidens", the bar before rehearsal 99 is in {{music|time|8|4}}.<ref>Stravinsky 1970, 99.</ref> *''De Staat'' by [[Louis Andriessen]]. Bars 686–87 are in {{music|time|8|4}}.<ref name=":3">Andriessen 1976, 1–4, 82–88, 90, 92, 95–97, 99, 119.</ref> *[[String Quartet No. 2 (Britten)|String Quartet No. 2, Op. 36]] (1945), by [[Benjamin Britten]]. Movement I, bars 3 and 12 after rehearsal '''K''' are in {{music|time|8|4}}.<ref>Britten 1946, 14–15.</ref> *[[Symphony No. 3 (Davies)|Symphony No. 3]] by [[Peter Maxwell Davies]]. Movement I has two bars of {{music|time|8|4}} (divided {{serif|'''3+2+3'''}}) at rehearsal '''N'''.<ref>Davies 1985, 48–49.</ref>
==={{music|time|8|8}}===
*[[Concerto for Orchestra (Bartók)|Concerto for Orchestra]] by [[Béla Bartók]]. Movement IV has three bars of {{music|time|8|8}} in the strings at rehearsal 75.<ref>Bartók 1993, 72.</ref> *"De elegia prima" from ''[[Threni (Stravinsky)|Threni]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]]. Bars 83–84, 91, and 165 are in {{music|time|8|8}}.<ref>Stravinsky 1958, 11–12 and 19.</ref> *''[[Diversions for Piano Left Hand and Orchestra]]''[[Diversions for Piano Left Hand and Orchestra|, Op. 21]], by [[Benjamin Britten]]. In Variation IV, bars 171, 175–77, 181, and 187–91 are in {{music|time|8|8}}.<ref>Britten 1941, 30–32.</ref> *''[[Fancy Free (ballet)|Fancy Free]]'' by [[Leonard Bernstein]]. In the fourth number, "Pas de deux", bars 324–25, 355–57, 359–61 are in {{music|time|8|8}}.<ref>Bernstein 1950, 48, 52–54.</ref> *''[[Mikrokosmos (Bartók)|Mikrokosmos]]'' by [[Béla Bartók]]. **No. 151, "Six Dances in Bulgarian Rhythm" 4, is in {{music|time|3+2+3|8}}.<ref>Bartók 1940, 6:45–48.</ref> **No. 153, "Six Dances in Bulgarian Rhythm" 6, is in {{music|time|3+3+2|8}}.<ref>Bartók 1940, 6:51–55.</ref> *''[[Music for Strings, Percussion, and Celesta]]'' by [[Béla Bartók]]. **Movement I, bars 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15, 19, 22, 26–27, 29, 38–40, 46, 53, 69, 71, 73, 75, 83, and 85 are in {{music|time|8|8}}<ref>Bartók 1937, 1–5, 7–8, 10.</ref> **Movement IV, bars 204, 207, 210, 213 are in {{music|time|8|8}}.<ref>Bartók 1937, 130–33.</ref> *''[[Petrushka (ballet)|Petrushka]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]]. One bar before and five bars after rehearsal 4 superimposes a bar of {{music|time|8|8}} in piccolo 1 & 2, ob. 1 & 2, and trumpet 1, and piccolo 1 & 2, ob. 1–3, cornet 1 & trumpet 1, respectively against {{music|time|3|4}} in the rest of the orchestra.<ref>Stravinsky n.d., 11–12.</ref> * Piano Sonata No. 2 ("The Airplane"), by [[George Antheil]]. One of the bars is in {{music|time|8|8}}.<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J4on2sedCNg&list=RD8cLvxekUaps&index=28|title=Antheil – Piano Sonata No. 2 'The Airplane'|last=musicaignotus|first=|date=14 October 2009|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> *Sonata No. 1, by [[Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji]]. One of the bars is in {{music|time|8|8}}.<ref name="auto2">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yTugy32wY5k|title=Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji – Sonata No. 1|last=Timothy Smith|first=|date=26 September 2015|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> *''De Staat'' by [[Louis Andriessen]]. Bars 5, 8, 10, 12–16, 54–57, 83–84, 87–88, 582, 590, 602, 610, 612, 625, 630, 644, 647–48, 650, 663, 695, 707, 851, and 853 are in {{music|time|8|8}}.<ref name=":3" /> *[[Symphony No. 1 (Mahler)|Symphony No. 1]] by [[Gustav Mahler]]. In Movement IV, the bar before rehearsal number 40 is in {{music|time|8|8}}.<ref>http://imslp.eu/files/imglnks/euimg/6/63/IMSLP06376-Mahler_-_Symphony_No.1_Mvt.IV_(complete_score).pdf</ref> *[[Symphony No. 3 (Davies)|Symphony No. 3]] by [[Peter Maxwell Davies]]. Third movement has one bar of {{music|time|8|8}} before rehearsal '''X'''.<ref>Davies 1985, 202.</ref>
==={{music|time|8|16}}===
*''The Cry of Anubis'', for tuba and orchestra by [[Harrison Birtwistle]]. Bars 33, 36, and 45–46 are in {{music|time|8|16}}.<ref>Birtwistle 1996, 6–7 and 9.</ref> *''[[The Flood (Stravinsky)|The Flood]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]]. Bars 406, 414, 422, 427, 432, 440, and 448 are in {{music|time|8|16}} time, all divided {{serif|'''3+2+3'''}}.<ref>Stravinsky 1962, 54, 56, 58, 60–61, 63, and 66.</ref> *''[[Histoire du soldat]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]] has one bar in {{music|time|8|16}} time, at the fourth bar following rehearsal 35, in the movement "Ragtime".<ref>Stravinsky 1924, 50.</ref> *''[[Requiem Canticles]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]]. The interlude has bar 156 in {{music|time|8|16}} time.<ref>Stravinsky 1967, 19.</ref>
== Upper number of 9 == Time signatures that group nine beats into {{serif|'''3+3+3'''}} are very common in music. This section only lists other groupings, such as {{serif|'''2+3+2+2'''}}. <!--********************************************************************************************** BEFORE YOU ADD ANY NEW SONGS, PLEASE MAKE SURE YOU CITE A RELIABLE SOURCE! TRYING TO INTERPRET THE TIMING YOURSELF, NO MATTER HOW SURE YOU ARE, COUNTS AS ORIGINAL RESEARCH! (see [[WP:OR]]) IF YOU WISH TO CITE A SOURCE, PLEASE SEE [[WP:CITE]] – ANY UNSOURCED ADDITIONS WILL BE REMOVED! DO NOT USE ANOTHER WIKIPEDIA PAGE AS A SOURCE EITHER!
*************************************************************************************************--> === {{music|time|9|4}} ===
* "The Count of Tuscany" by [[Dream Theater]]. The verse riff is in {{music|time|9|4}}, with a rhythm of {{music|time|3+2+2+3+3+2+3|8}}.<ref>Dream Theater Black Clouds and Silver Linings Authentic Guitar TAB, transcribed by Jordan Baker. 2009, 138</ref>
=== {{music|time|9|8}} ===
* "Apocalypse in {{music|time|9|8}}" by [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]]. Penultimate movement of the "[[Supper's Ready]]" suite, rhythm section plays a {{music|time|9|8}} riff as {{serif|'''3+2+4'''}}, organ solo plays polymetrically over this (sometimes {{music|time|4|4}}, sometimes {{music|time|7|4}}.)<ref>Seconds Out Songbook 1978 Wise Publications</ref> *"Big Lie Small World", by [[Sting (musician)|Sting]] is in {{music|time|9|8}} with varying division.<ref name="auto3">Gable 2009, 91.</ref> * "[[Blue Rondo à la Turk]]" (1959) by [[Dave Brubeck|the Dave Brubeck Quartet]], from the album ''[[Time Out (album)|Time Out]]'' – Played as {{serif|'''2+2+2+3'''}} and {{serif|'''3+3+3'''}}, with some alternating sections of {{music|time|4|4}}.<ref>Dryden, Ken. "[{{Allmusic|class=song|id=t803311|pure_url=yes}} Blue Rondo a la Turk]", Allmusic: "unusual time signature of {{music|time|9|8}}".</ref> *''Estancia'' by [[Alberto Ginastera]]. The refrain of "Los peones de hacienda", at rehearsal numbers 62, 65, 67, 68, 69+3, and 70 is marked "{{music|time|9|8}} ({{music|time|3|4}} – {{music|time|3|8}})"; the remainder is variously in {{music|time|6|8}}, {{music|time|3|4}}, {{music|time|5|8}}, and {{music|time|7|8}}.<ref>Ginastera 1955, 17–20.</ref> *"[[I Hung My Head]]", by [[Sting (musician)|Sting]] is in {{music|time|2+3+2+2|8}}.<ref name="auto3" /> *''[[Mikrokosmos (Bartók)|Mikrokosmos]]'' by [[Béla Bartók]] **No. 148, "Six Dances in Bulgarian Rhythm" 1, is in {{music|time|4+2+3|8}}.<ref>Bartók 1940, 6:35–38.</ref> ** No. 152, "Six Dances in Bulgarian Rhythm" 5, is in {{music|time|2+2+2+3|8}}.<ref>Bartók 1940, 6:48–50.</ref> *"Niska Banja," SATB choral arrangement by Nick Page of a Serbian Gypsy dance, is in {{music|time|2+2+2+3|8}}.<ref>Page 1989.</ref>
=== {{music|time|9|32}} ===
*''Un Vitrail et des Oiseaux'' by [[Olivier Messiaen]] uses {{music|time|3+2+2+2|32}}.<ref name="DonByrd">{{cite web|url=http://homes.soic.indiana.edu/donbyrd/CMNExtremes.htm|title=Extremes of Conventional Music Notation|publisher=}}</ref>

({{music|time|10|4}} after a [[anacrusis|pick-up measure]] of two beats; divided {{serif|'''4+4+2'''}})<ref>http://www.talkbass.com/forum/f22/how-do-you-figure-out-time-signatures-476426/ {{verify credibility|date=April 2013}}<!--This appears to be nothing but a blog.--></ref> *"[[Just Like You Imagined]]" by [[Nine Inch Nails]]. ({{music|time|10|4}})<ref>Banks 2009.</ref> *"[[Playing in the Band]]" by the [[Grateful Dead]] (notated as {{music|time|4+2+4|4}}). ({{music|time|10|4}})<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stason.org/TULARC/music-bands/grateful-dead/30-The-Eleven-and-Other-Rhythmic-Oddities-Grateful-Dead.html|title=The Eleven and Other Rhythmic Oddities (Grateful Dead)|publisher=|accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref> * "Rabbit" by [[This Town Needs Guns]] has parts in {{music|time|10|4}}.<ref name="rabbit">Dreiblats 2013.</ref> *[[String Quartet No. 2 (Britten)|String Quartet No. 2, op. 35]] (1945), by [[Benjamin Britten]]. Movement I, fourth bar after rehearsal '''K''' ("tranquillo, ''lusingando''") is in {{music|time|10|4}}.<ref>Britten 1946, 14.</ref> * "Testotyrannosaurus" by [[Hail the Sun]] contains some parts in {{music|time|10|4}}, and {{music|time|11|4}}.<ref name="testotyrannosaurus">{{cite web|author=[[Hail the Sun]]|title=Testotyrannosaurus.pdf|url=https://app.box.com/s/my54x6y5ihbqcnk5tzy8|publisher=Hail the Sun|accessdate=11 May 2016|format=PDF|date=19 February 2013}}</ref><!-- https://www.facebook.com/hailthesun/posts/505994562776647 --> * "[[Thick as a Brick]]" by [[Jethro Tull (band)|Jethro Tull]]. The second section of the first part of the song is in {{music|time|10|4}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UncommonTime|title=Uncommon Time|publisher=|accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref> *"Wanderlove" by [[Mason Williams]]. ({{music|time|10|4}})<ref>Liner notes to ''The Mason Williams Phonograph Record'' Warner Brothers LP, WS 1729. Burbank: Warner Brothers-Seven Arts Records, 1968.</ref>
=== {{music|time|10|8}} === * "Erotomania" by [[Dream Theater]], the first 3 bars of the intro progression are in {{music|time|10|8}}.<ref>{{Citation|last=TheDeftonesVault|title=Dream Theater- Erotomania [Instrumental]|date=2013-08-21|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V3JQyV4dUKM|accessdate=2016-03-24}}</ref> * "[[Happiness is a Warm Gun]]", by The Beatles. The first part includes {{music|time|4|4}}, {{music|time|2|4}}, and {{music|time|5|4}}; the second part includes {{music|time|3|8}}; and third part {{music|time|9|8}} and {{music|time|10|8}}.<ref>http://i.imgur.com/uGO9LL6.png</ref> The finale includes 1 bar of {{music|time|12|4}}. "[T]he changes of meter either between or within every section establish themselves as a kind of leitmotif." (Alan Pollack's 'Notes On' series, [http://www.icce.rug.nl/~soundscapes/DATABASES/AWP/hiawg.shtml no. 136]). *"Nostalgia" by [[Yanni]]. ({{music|time|10|8}})<ref name="yanni">{{Cite book|title=The Best of Yanni; 11 selections from his top recordings|last=Yanni|publisher=[[Hal Leonard Publishing]]|year=1993|page=16|authorlink=}}</ref> *Piano Sonata No. 2 ("The Airplane"), by [[George Antheil]]. One of the bars is in {{music|time|10|8}}.<ref name="auto1" /> *''Sketch'', Op. 1 No. 7, by [[Alexei Stanchinsky]] ({{music|time|10|8}}).<ref name="stanchinskyop1" /> *Sonata No. 1, by [[Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji]]. One of the bars is in {{music|time|10|8}}.<ref name="auto2" /> *''[[Threni (Stravinsky)|Threni, id est Lamentationes Jeremiae Prophetae]]'', by [[Igor Stravinsky]]. "Solacium", part 3 of "De Elegia Tertia".<ref>Bars 2–5 are in {{music|time|10|8}} time (Stravinsky 1958, 52).</ref>

== Upper number of 11 ==
==={{music|time|11|4}}===
*"Cigne je suis" published in the collection ''Airs a III. IIII. V. et VI. parties'' (première livre, 1608) by [[Claude Le Jeune]] is barred as {{music|time|11|4}}.<ref>Le Jeune 1951–59, 2:85–88.</ref> *"Crowned & Kissed" by [[Esperanza Spalding]]. The two-bar chorus groove is in {{music|time|11|4}} time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bassplayer.com/artists/1171/esperanza-spalding-e-harmony/26667| title=Esperanza Spalding: E-Harmony| author=Jisi, Chris|year=2012 |accessdate=April 29, 2015}}</ref> * "Eight Ball, Coroner's Pocket" by [[Hail the Sun]], intro is composed in {{music|time|9|4}}, and {{music|time|11|4}}.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Hail the Sun]]|title=Eight Ball, Coroner's Pocket.pdf|url=https://app.box.com/s/n2seb7pdrvdu7jq0urp2|publisher=Hail the Sun|accessdate=11 May 2016|format=PDF|date=13 January 2013}}</ref> *"Eleven Four", by [[Paul Desmond]] and recorded by the [[Dave Brubeck Quartet]] ({{music|time|11|4}}).<ref>Howard Brubeck (ed.), ''Dave Brubeck Deluxe Piano Album'', (San Francisco: Derry Music Co., 1965), pp. 22–28.</ref> *''In Nomine IX'', for harpsichord, by [[John Bull (composer)|John Bull]]. {{music|time|11|4}}, though it is not notated as such, either in the original manuscript or the new edition.<ref>J. A. Fuller Maitland and W. Barclay Squire (eds.), ''The Fitzwilliam Virginal Book'', vol. 2 (Leipzig: Breitkopf und Härtel, 1899; reprinted New York: Dover Publications, Inc., 1963), 34–39.</ref> * ''Mädchentotenlieder'', by [[Bo Nilsson]]. Bar 74 is in {{music|time|11|4}} time.<ref>Nilsson 1958, 7.</ref> *''[[The Rite of Spring]]'' by [[Igor Stravinsky]]. The bar immediately before the section "The Chosen One" is in {{music|time|11|4}}.<ref name="rite">http://petruccilibrary.us/Scores/scores/Stravinsky_Igor_1971/Stravinsky_-_RiteOfSpring_Piano4Hands.pdf</ref> *"Testotyrannosaurus" by [[Hail the Sun]] contains some parts in {{music|time|10|4}}, and {{music|time|11|4}}.<ref name="testotyrannosaurus" /> *"Where but for Caravan Would I Be" (1969), by [[Caravan (band)|Caravan]].<ref name="Macan">Macan 1997, 48.</ref> * "[[Whipping Post (song)|Whipping Post]]", by [[The Allman Brothers Band]]. (Begins with a two-bar {{music|time|11|4}} riff).<ref name="Poe2006">{{cite book|author=Randy Poe|title=Skydog: The Duane Allman Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nBC5wukMKXIC&pg=PA131|accessdate=11 April 2012|date=20 September 2006|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|isbn=978-0-87930-891-9|page=131}}</ref>
==={{music|time|11|8}}===
*''[[Bachianas Brasileiras#Bachianas Brasileiras No. 9|Bachianas Brasileiras No. 9]]'', by [[Heitor Villa-Lobos]]. Movement II is in {{music|time|11|8}}<ref>Villa-Lobos 1969, 3–18.</ref> *"Blockhead", by [[Devo]]. Verses are in {{music|time|11|8}} time, choruses in {{music|time|4|4}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailyvault.com/toc.php5?review=1171|title=The Daily Vault Music Reviews :|publisher=|accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref> * "[[The Eleven]]", by the [[Grateful Dead]].<ref>[http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~./gdead/faq/eleven.html rec.music.gdead FAQ].{{Verify credibility|date=March 2014}}<!--Self-published blog?--> </ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://arts.ucsc.edu/gdead/agdl/eleven.html|title=The Annotated "The Eleven"|publisher=|accessdate=2017-03-08}}</ref> * "Eleven" by [[Primus (band)|Primus]]. The song is mainly in {{music|time|11|8}}, the chorus has one bar in {{music|time|9|8}}, and after two bars of {{music|time|11|8}} a bar in {{music|time|12|8}}.<ref>Primus (musical group), ''Primus Anthology: A thru<!--NB: misspelled exactly this way in the printed title of the book.--> N: For Guitar and Bass'', transcribed by Jeff Jacobsen (New York: Cherry Lane Music, 2000), 17–20. {{ISBN|1575601540}}.</ref> *"[[Here Comes the Sun]]" (1969), written by [[The Beatles]]' [[George Harrison]]. The song features common {{music|time|4|4}} time in the verses and a compound sequence of {{music|time|11|8}} {{serif|'''+'''}} {{music|time|4|4}} {{serif|'''+'''}} {{music|time|7|8}} in the bridge, phrasing interludes that Harrison drew from Indian music influences.{{sfn|Pollack|1999}}{{sfn|Pedler|2003|p=555}}<ref>"The meters of these three measures are {{music|time|11|8}}, {{music|time|4|4}}, and {{music|time|7|8}}, respectively. The special effect of running even eighth notes accented as if triplets against the grain of the underlying backbeat is carried to a point more reminiscent of Stravinsky than of the Beatles" (Alan Pollack's 'Notes On' series, [http://www.icce.rug.nl/~soundscapes/DATABASES/AWP/hcts.shtml no. 183]).</ref> * "Losing It" by [[Rush (band)|Rush]]. Intro and verses are composed out of ten bars in {{music|time|5|8}}, other parts are in {{music|time|11|8}}.<ref>{{cite web|author=Peart, Neil |url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdFPE.asp?ppn=MN0061717 |title=Rush – Losing It Sheet Music (Digital Download) |website=Musicnotes.com |date=2010-10-07 |accessdate=2017-03-08}}</ref><ref>Haigh n.d.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drumlessons.com/drummers/neil-peart/ |title=" Neil Peart Biography, Drum Videos and Pictures | Famous Drummers |website=Drumlessons.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-14}}</ref> *''[[Mario Kart 64]]'' (video game), music by Kenta Nagata, at the [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sVdxrERxQo8 race results screen].<ref>Elroy 2008.{{Verify credibility|date=June 2013}}<!--As a blog, is this really a Reliable Source?--></ref> *"Man-Erg" (1971), by [[Van der Graaf Generator]].<ref>Macan 1997, 48–49.</ref> *Piano Sonata No. 2 in G major by [[Alexei Stanchinsky]]. Movement II is in {{music|time|11|8}}.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110718113558/http://imslp.info/files/imglnks/usimg/9/9d/IMSLP15483-Stanchinksy_-_Piano_Sonata_No.2.pdf]</ref> *''[[A próle do bébé]]'', by [[Heitor Villa-Lobos]]. The first and last measures of the fourth movement{{Clarify|date=January 2017}}<!--There are two "fourth movements": one in each of the two suites. Which one is this?--> are in {{music|time|11|8}}, divided into {{music|time|6|8}} or {{music|time|3|4}}, and {{music|time|5|8}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://imslp.org/wiki/A_prole_do_beb%C3%AA_No.2,_W180_(Villa-Lobos,_Heitor)|title=A prole do bebê No.2, W180 (Villa-Lobos, Heitor) – IMSLP/Petrucci Music Library: Free Public Domain Sheet Music|publisher=}}</ref> * "Serenade", a wedding recessional by [[Derek Bourgeois]]. The beginning and ending sections are in {{music|time|11|8}}.<ref name="reynish">{{cite web|url=http://www.timreynish.com/repcompbourgeois1.html|title=Derek Bourgeois: An Assessment of his music in Two Parts|author=Reynish, Tim|accessdate=2017-03-08}}</ref><ref name="howardpac">{{cite web|url=http://www.howard.andrews.edu/news/113/|title=Pops Concert Program Notes|date=March 8, 2008|publisher=Howard Performing Arts Center, Andrews University|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719135119/http://www.howard.andrews.edu/news/113/|archive-date=July 19, 2011|dead-url=yes|accessdate=November 8, 2009}}</ref> *''Sketch'', Op. 1 No. 5, by [[Alexei Stanchinsky]] ({{music|time|11|8}}).<ref name="stanchinskyop1" /> * Sonata No. 1, by [[Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji]]. One of the bars is in {{music|time|11|8}}.<ref name="auto2" />

=== {{music|time|12|32}} ===
*[[Piano Sonata No. 32 (Beethoven)|Piano Sonata No. 32]] in C minor, Op. 111, by [[Ludwig van Beethoven]]. Movement II is in {{music|time|12|32}} from bars 48 to 64.<ref name="DonByrd" />

* "[[Golden Brown]]" by [[The Stranglers]]. Bars 356 and 517 are in {{music|time|13|4}}.<ref name=":4">Andriessen 1976, 46, 69, and 101.</ref> * "[[Starless]]" (1974), by [[King Crimson]].<ref name="Macan49">Macan 1997, 49.</ref>
==={{music|time|13|8}}===
* "The Becoming" by [[Nine Inch Nails]]. Begins in a {{music|time|13|8}} time signature and changes to {{music|time|6|8}} at the 3-minute mark.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ninwiki.com/The_Becoming#The_Becoming|title=The Becoming|publisher=|accessdate=2017-03-08}}</ref> * "I Will Be Absorbed", by [[Egg (band)|Egg]].<ref name="Macan49" /> * "One Word" by [[Mahavishnu Orchestra]] has a section in {{music|time|13|8}} after the drum solo (just over eight and a half minutes in).<ref>Jerry 2014.</ref> *''[[A próle do bébé]] No. 2'', by [[Heitor Villa-Lobos]]. A measure in the fourth movement, "O cachorrinho de borracha", is in {{music|time|13|8}}, divided into {{music|time|6|8}} or {{music|time|3|4}}, and {{music|time|7|8}}. Two measures in the ninth movement, "O lobozinho de vidro", are also in {{music|time|13|16}}.<ref>http://imslp.org/wiki/A_prole_do_beb%C3%AA_No.2,_W180_(Villa-Lobos,_Heitor) {{Page needed|date=January 2017}}<!--measure numbers would be just as good.--></ref> * "Serenade", a wedding recessional by [[Derek Bourgeois]]. The middle section is in {{music|time|13|8}}.<ref name="reynish" /><ref name="howardpac" /> * "Skimbleshanks" from [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]]'s musical ''[[Cats (musical)|Cats]]''. Introduction and chorus are in {{music|time|13|8}} ({{serif|'''3+3+3+4'''}}). Verses in {{music|time|4|4}}.<ref>Andrew Lloyd Webber, T. S. Eliot – "Cats" ''Hal Leonard'' (HL00359466), {{ISBN|0-88188-447-2}}</ref> * Sonata No. 1, by [[Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji]]. One of the bars is in {{music|time|13|8}}.<ref name="auto2" /> *''De Staat'' by [[Louis Andriessen]]. Bars 356 and 517 are in {{music|time|13|4}}, while bar 724 is in {{music|time|13|8}}.<ref name=":4" /> *"[[13th August (instrumental)|13th August]]" by [[FromUz]] ({{music|time|13|8}}).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kenwestphal.com/CDart/Overlook8-9.html|title=Ken Westphal Illustration & Design|publisher=|accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref> * "[[Turn It on Again]]" by [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]]. The verses and choruses are in {{music|time|13|8}}. Other parts are in {{music|time|8|8}}, and {{music|time|5|8}}.<ref>Genesis 2001, 334–337.</ref>
==={{music|time|13|16}}===
*"78341316" by [[deadmau5]] uses the time signatures {{music|time|7|8}} and {{music|time|13|16}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/5q3mUkux9V/|title=deadmau5 on Instagram}}</ref> *''[[The Terminator]]'' main theme, by [[Brad Fiedel]] ({{music|time|13|16}}).<ref>Stevenson 2014.</ref>

Main Allegro section in {{music|time|15|8}}.<ref>Medtner 1998, 134.</ref>{{Vague|date=January 2012}}<!--non-quintuple division of the bars needs to be specified; otherwise this example belongs in the article on [[Quintuple meter]], not here.--> * "Strong One" from the ''[[Mother 3]]'' soundtrack<ref name="danbruno">{{cite web|url=http://danbruno.net/writing/mother3/|title=danbruno.net: Battle music in Mother 3|publisher=}}</ref> * "[[Tubular Bells]]" by [[Mike Oldfield]]. The first riff in {{music|time|15|8}} is made of two bars. The first bar is in {{music|time|7|8}}, the second bar is in {{music|time|8|8}}.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Changeling – Autobiography of Mike Oldfield|last=Oldfield|first=Mike|publisher=Virgin Books|year=2007|isbn=978-1-85227-381-1|page=111}}</ref>
==={{music|time|15|16}}=== *''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' (1986) by [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]]: "Notes" and "Notes II" each contain multiple sections of {{music|time|15|16}}.{{Clarify|date=March 2018}}<!--Are these in irregular groupings, or in the relatively common {{serif|'''3+3+3+3+3'''}} "compound quintuple" meter? If the latter, then this example belongs in the Quintuple meter article, rather than here.--><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Phantom of the Opera Libretto/ Vocal Score|last=Llyod Webber|first=Andrew|publisher=The Really Useful Group Ltd.|year=1987|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> * ''Robert Browning Overture'', by [[Charles Ives]] includes measures in {{music|time|15|16}} time.<ref name="Read157">Read 1964, 157.</ref> * ''De Staat'' by [[Louis Andriessen]]. Bars 501 and 535–36 are in {{music|time|15|16}} time, divided {{serif|'''4+4+4+3'''}} (in b. 501 some layers are in {{serif|'''3+3+3+3+3'''}} and {{serif|'''3+4+4+3'''}}).<ref>Andriessen 1976, 65 and 74.</ref> *[[String Quartet No. 1 (Carter)|String Quartet No. 1]] (1950–51), by [[Elliott Carter]] includes measures in {{music|time|15|16}} time.<ref name="Read157" /> * String Quartet No. 1 (1949), by [[Leon Kirchner]] includes measures in {{music|time|15|16}} time.<ref name="Read157" /> *[[String Quartet No. 2 (Carter)|String Quartet No. 2]] (1959), by [[Elliott Carter]] includes measures in {{music|time|15|16}} time.<ref name="Read157" />

== Upper number of 18 == {{see also|Sextuple meter}}
=== {{music|time|18|8}} ===
* "[[Birds of Fire]]" by [[Mahavishnu Orchestra]]. Guitar plays {{serif|'''5+5+5+3'''}} while drums play {{serif|'''6+6+6'''}}. Violin from time to time plays {{serif|'''3+3+2+3+3+2+2'''}}.<ref name="mahavishnu">John McLaughlin, ''John McLaughlin and the Mahavishnu Orchestra: John McLaughlin's Scores to 28 Classic Recordings'' (Van Nuys: Alfred Publishing, 2006): {{Page needed|date=March 2008}}<!--This book has got 152 pages in it—surely this one song or the documentation of its meter doesn't occupy all of them!-->. {{ISBN|0-7390-4255-6}}.</ref> *[[Esquisses (Alkan)|''49 Esquisses'']] by [[Charles-Valentin Alkan]]. No. 12, ''Barcarollette'', is in {{music|time|18|8}}, as [[Compound meter (music)|compound]] [[Septuple meter|sextuple meter]].<ref>Alkan n.d. (ca.1862), 1:25.</ref>
==={{music|time|18|16}}===
*''[[Don Rodrigo]]'' by [[Alberto Ginastera]]. "Interludium III" is in {{music|time|18|16}} meter, except the last three bars, which are in {{music|time|3|4}}.<ref>Ginastera 1969, 79–86.</ref> *''Four Etudes'', op. 2, by [[Sergei Prokofiev]]. The second étude uses {{music|time|18|16}} in one hand against {{music|time|4|4}} in the other.<ref>Prokofiev 1955, 1:9–14.</ref> *''Fünf Klavierstücke'', Op. 23 by [[Arnold Schoenberg]]. Movement III, bars 26 to 30 inclusive are in {{music|time|18|16}}.<ref>http://petruccilibrary.ca/download.php?file=files/imglnks/caimg/c/c8/IMSLP00783-Schoenberg_op23_No3.pdf</ref> *''[[Goldberg Variations]]'', by [[Johann Sebastian Bach]]. Variatio 26, a 2 Clav. uses {{music|time|18|16}} in one hand against {{music|time|3|4}} in the other, exchanging hands at intervals until the last five bars where both hands are in {{music|time|18|16}}.<ref>Bach 1968, 98–99.</ref>

IIII. V. et VI. parties'' (première livre, 1608). ==Fractional time signatures==
*''Driftwood Suite'', for piano, by [[Gardner Read]] uses {{music|time|{{frac|3|1|2}}|4}}, {{music|time|{{frac|4|1|2}}|4}}, and {{music|time|{{frac|5|1|2}}|4}}.<ref name="Read170" /> *''Intrada, nebst burlesquer Suite'', for two violins (the so-called "Gulliver Suite") by [[Georg Philipp Telemann]]. "Reverie der Laputier, nebst ihren Aufweckern" is in {{music|time|{{frac|3|2|2}}|4}}.<ref>Telemann 1728, 40; Zohn 2004, 247: "The ‘Reverie der Laputier, nebst ihren Aufweckern’ . . . teases the reader with a nonsensical time signature, {{music|time|{{frac|3|2|2}}|4}}, in an apparent allusion to the Laputians’ love for, and incompetence in, mathematics." Dietz Degan, the editor of Telemann 1970, transcribes this piece simply in {{music|time|2|2}}.</ref> *''[[Lincolnshire Posy]]'' by [[Percy Grainger]]. In movement V, "Lord Melbourne", some parts mark this measure as {{music|time|{{frac|1|1|2}}|4}} while others mark it as {{music|time|3|8}}. [http://imslp.nl/imglnks/usimg/f/f2/IMSLP338405-PMLP310471-LincolnshireTbn12.pdf This trombone part] has a bar of {{music|time|{{frac|1|1|2}}|4}} on the bottom of page 4.<ref name="imslp.org" /> It also contains {{music|time|{{frac|2|1|2}}|4}}.<ref name="imslp.org" /> *''Mädchentotenlieder'', by [[Bo Nilsson]]. **Bar 83 is in {{music|time|{{frac|4|3}}|4}} time.<ref>Nilsson 1958, 8; Read 1964, 172.</ref> **Bar 97 is in {{music|time|{{frac|3|5}}|4}} time.<ref>Nilsson 1958, 10; Read 1964, 172.</ref> **Bars 102 and 123 are in {{music|time|{{2/3}}|4}} time.<ref>Nilsson 1958, 10 & 12; Read 1964, 172.</ref> **Bar 112 is in {{music|time|{{frac|4|5}}|4}} time.<ref>Nilsson 1958, 11; Read 1964, 172.</ref> *''[[Le marteau sans maître]]'', by [[Pierre Boulez]]. Movement III "L'Artisanat furieux". **Bar 3 is in {{music|time|{{frac|4|3}}|2}} time.<ref>Boulez 1957, 18.</ref> **Bars 24, 35, and 43 are in {{music|time|{{2/3}}|4}} time.<ref>Boulez 1957, 19–20.</ref> *[[Piano Sonata No. 2 (Ives)|Piano Sonata No. 2, ''Concord, Mass., 1840–1860'']], by [[Charles Ives]]. In movement III "The Alcotts", bar 20 is in {{music|time|{{frac|4|1|2}}|4}} time.<ref>Ives 1920, 56.</ref> *[[Piano Sonata No. 3 (Chávez)|Piano Sonata No. 3]] by [[Carlos Chávez]]. Movement IV has measures in {{music|time|{{frac|2|1|2}}|4}}, {{music|time|{{frac|3|1|2}}|4}}, and {{music|time|{{frac|4|1|2}}|4}}.<ref name="auto">Chávez 1972, 17–20.</ref> *"[[Schism (song)|Schism]]" by [[Tool (band)|Tool]] is described by the band as largely in {{music|time|{{frac|6|1|2}}|8}} and includes numerous other times.<ref>Wagner 2010, 312–13.</ref> *''[[Sensemayá]]'' by [[Silvestre Revueltas]] includes three bars in {{music|time|{{frac|5|1|2}}|8}}.<ref>Revueltas 1949, 36.</ref> * ''Study in Sonority'' by [[Wallingford Riegger]] contains several {{music|time|{{frac|2|1|2}}|4}} bars.<ref name="Read170">Read 1964, 170.</ref> *''Touch Piece'', for piano, by [[Gardner Read]] uses {{music|time|{{frac|3|1|2}}|4}}, {{music|time|{{frac|4|1|2}}|4}}, and {{music|time|{{frac|5|1|2}}|4}}.<ref name="Read170" />
* "Upstart" by [[Don Ellis]] is in {{music|time|{{frac|3|2|3}}|4}} (originally written in {{music|time|11|8}}).<ref>Strait 2000, 56.</ref>
== Irrational time signatures == {{See also|Time signature#Irrational meters}}
*''L'Itoi Variations'' by [[Kyle Gann]]. Bar 275 is in {{music|time|2|3}} time.<ref name="Gann">{{cite web|url=http://www.artsjournal.com/postclassic/2008/03/dont_blame_me_it_was_henry_cow.html|title=Don't Blame Me, It Was Henry Cowell's Idea|date=15 March 2008|publisher=}}</ref> *[[Piano Sonata No. 3 (Chávez)|Piano Sonata No. 3]] by [[Carlos Chávez]]. In movement IV, bars 47, 49, 107, and 109 are in {{music|time|1|12}}.<ref>Chávez 1972, 16, 19.</ref>
==Combined unusual signatures== {{See also|Time signature#Mixed meters}}
*"O cachorrinho de borracha" (The Little Rubber Dog), No. 4 from ''[[A próle do bébé]] No. 2'' by [[Heitor Villa-Lobos]] mixes {{music|time|11|8}}, {{music|time|13|8}}, {{music|time|5|4}}, and {{music|time|8|4}} with the usual signatures {{music|time|3|4}} and {{music|time|4|4}}.<ref>Villa-Lobos 1927, 4:1–4.</ref> * "[[Firth of Fifth]]": Introduction, by [[Tony Banks (musician)|Tony Banks]] of [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]], mixes duple and quadruple meters with {{music|time|13|16}} and {{music|time|15|16}} signatures.<ref>Banks n.d.</ref> * "[[I Say a Little Prayer]]" by [[Dionne Warwick]] uses two measures of {{music|time|4|4}}, one measure of {{music|time|10|4}} and two measures of {{music|time|4|4}} for verses and {{music|time|11|4}} for its chorus.<ref>Sheet music, published by New Hidden Valley Music and Casa David, copyright 1966</ref> *''[[Klavierstücke (Stockhausen)#Klavierstück IX|Klavierstück IX]]'' (1954–55/61) by [[Karlheinz Stockhausen]] uses {{music|time|21|8}}, {{music|time|34|8}}, {{music|time|42|8}}, {{music|time|87|8}}, and {{music|time|142|8}}.<ref>Stockhausen 1967, 1, 6, and 7.</ref> *''[[Zeitmaße]]'' by [[Karlheinz Stockhausen]] uses {{music|time|1|2}}, {{music|time|1|8}}, {{music|time|1|16}}, {{music|time|2|16}}, {{music|time|2|32}}, {{music|time|3|16}}, {{music|time|3|32}}, {{music|time|4|16}}, {{music|time|8|8}}, {{music|time|8|32}}, {{music|time|11|16}}, {{music|time|12|32}}, {{music|time|17|32}}, {{music|time|23|32}}, and {{music|time|30|32}}.<ref name="DonByrd" /><ref>Stockhausen 1957, 52, 60–62, 66.</ref>

[[File:Ethnolinguistic groups in Yunnan Province (1971).jpg|thumb|right|Ethnolinguistic groups in Yunnan, China]] [[File:Ethnolinguistic map of Burma 1972 en.svg|thumb|right|Ethnolinguistic groups in Burma {{legend|#ff7100|Burmese}} {{legend|#ffb173|other Tibeto-Burman}} ]] The '''Lolo-Burmese''' languages (also '''Burmic''' languages) of [[Burma]] and [[Southern China]] form a coherent branch of the [[Sino-Tibetan languages|Sino-Tibetan family]].
==Names== Until ca. 1950, the endonym ''Lolo'' was written with [[Graphic pejoratives in written Chinese|derogatory characters in Chinese]], and for this reason has sometimes been avoided. Shafer (1966–1974) used the term "Burmic" for the Lolo-Burmese languages. The Chinese term is ''Mian–Yi'', after the Chinese name for Burmese and one of several words for Tai, reassigned to replace ''Lolo'' by the Chinese government after 1950.<ref name="Bradley Burmic">{{cite journal | given=David | surname=Bradley | title=The Characteristics of the Burmic Family of Tibeto-Burman | journal=Language and Linguistics | year=2012 | volume=13 | issue=1 | pages=171–192 | url=http://www.ling.sinica.edu.tw/files/publication/j2012_1_08_4916.pdf }}</ref>
==Possible languages== The position of [[Naxish languages|Naxi]] (Moso) within the family is unclear, and it is often left as a third branch besides Loloish and Burmish. Lama (2012) considers it to be a branch of Loloish, while [[Guillaume Jacques]] has suggested that it is a [[Qiangic languages|Qiangic]] language.
The [[Pyu language (Burma)|Pyu language]] that preceded Burmese in Burma is sometimes linked to the Lolo-Burmese family, but there is no good evidence for any particular classification, and it is best left unclassified within Sino-Tibetan.
Löffler (1966) and Bradley (1997) consider the [[Mru language]] to be closely related to or part of Lolo-Burmese,<ref>{{cite journal | surname=Löffler | given=Lorenz G. | year=1966 | title=The contribution of Mru to Sino-Tibetan linguistics | journal=Zeitschrift der deutschen morgenländischen Gesellschaft | volume=116 | number=1 | pages=118–159 | jstor=43369896 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | given=David | surname=Bradley | chapter=Tibeto-Burman languages and classification | chapter-url=http://sealang.net/sala/archives/pdf8/bradley1997tibeto-burman.pdf | pages=1–71 | title=Tibeto-Burman languages of the Himalayas, Papers in South East Asian linguistics | location=Canberra | publisher=Pacific Linguistics | year=1997 }}</ref> while [[James A. Matisoff|Matisoff]] includes Mruic in the [[Northeast India]]n [[linguistic area|areal group]].<ref>{{cite book | given=James A. | surname=Matisoff | title=Handbook of Proto-Tibeto-Burman: System and Philosophy of Sino-Tibetan Reconstruction | location=Berkeley | publisher=[[University of California Press]] | year=2003 | isbn=978-0-520-09843-5 | url=http://escholarship.org/uc/item/19d79619 | page=6 }}</ref>
[[Pai-lang language|Pai-lang]], attested from the 3rd century, is Lolo-Burmese, perhaps Loloish.
==External relationships== [[Guillaume Jacques]] & Alexis Michaud (2011)<ref name="Jacques">{{cite journal | given1=Guillaume | surname1=Jacques | given2=Alexis | surname2=Michaud | title=Approaching the historical phonology of three highly eroded Sino-Tibetan languages | journal=Diachronica | year=2011 | volume=28 | pages=468–498 | doi=10.1075/dia.28.4.02jac.additional | doi-access=free }}</ref> argue for a '''[[Burmo-Qiangic languages|Burmo-Qiangic]]''' branch with two primary subbranches, Na-[[Qiangic languages|Qiangic]] (i.e. Naxi-Qiangic) and Lolo-Burmese. Similarly, [[David Bradley (linguist)|David Bradley]] (2008)<ref>Bradley, David. 2008. ''The Position of Namuyi in Tibeto-Burman''.</ref> also proposes an '''Eastern Tibeto-Burman''' branch that includes the two subbranches of Burmic ({{sc|aka}} Lolo-Burmese) and Qiangic.
==Internal classification== Bradley (1997, quoted in Peiros 1997) gives the following classification for the Lolo-Burmese languages. In later publications, in place of ''Loloish'', David Bradley instead uses the term ''Ngwi'' based on a conservative [[Exonym and endonym|autonym]] in the [[Sanie language]].<ref>{{cite journal | given=David | surname=Bradley | title=Sanie and language loss in China | journal=International Journal of the Sociology of Language | year=2005 | volume=2005 | issue=173 | pages=159–176 | doi=10.1515/ijsl.2005.2005.173.159 }}</ref>
*'''Lolo-Burmese''' **[[Mru language|Mru]] **Core Lolo-Burmese ***Ugong–Burmish ****[[Ugong language|Ugong]] ****[[Burmish languages|Burmish]] ***[[Loloish languages|Loloish]] (Ngwi)
Lama (2012), in a study of 36 languages, finds the [[Mondzish languages|Mondzish]] cluster ([[Mantsi language|Mondzi]]–[[Maang language|Maang]], Mantsi–Mo'ang) to be divergent. He did not include Mru or Ugong.
*'''Lolo-Burmese''' (Niso-Burmic) **[[Mondzish languages|Mondzish]] **Core Lolo-Burmese ***[[Burmish languages|Burmish]] (Burmic) ***[[Loloish languages|Loloish]] (Nisoic)
Lama (2012) recognizes 9 unambiguous coherent groups of Lolo-Burmese languages, whereas Bradley considers there to be 5 groups (Burmish, Southern Ngwi, Northern Ngwi, Southeastern Ngwi, and Central Ngwi).
#[[Mondzish languages|Mondzish]] #[[Burmish languages|Burmish]] #[[Hanoish languages|Hanoish]] #[[Lahoish languages|Lahoish]] #[[Naxish languages|Naxish]] #[[Nusoish languages|Nusoish]] #[[Kazhuoish languages|Kazhuoish]] #[[Lisoish languages|Lisoish]] #[[Nisoish languages|Nisoish]]
