revision.text:
{{Nationalism sidebar|Types}} '''Ultranationalism''' is an "extreme [[nationalism]] that promotes the interest of one state or people above all others", or simply "extreme devotion to one's own nation".<ref>[https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/us/ultranationalism Ultranationalism]. Oxford English Dictionary. Retrieved 29 June 2017.</ref><ref>[https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/ultranationalism Ultranationalism]. Collins English Dictionary. Retrieved 29 June 2017.</ref>
Ultranationalism combined with the notion of national rebirth is a key foundation of [[fascism]].<ref>Roger Griffin, "Nationalism" in Cyprian Blamires, ed., ''World Fascism: A Historical Encyclopedia'', vol. 2 (Santa Barbara, California: ABC-CLIO, 2006), pp. 451–53.</ref>
According to [[Janusz Bugajski]], "in its most extreme or developed forms, ultra-nationalism resembles fascism, marked by a xenophobic disdain of other nations, support for [[authoritarian]] political arrangements verging on [[totalitarianism]], and a mythical emphasis on the "organic unity" between a charismatic leader, an organizationally amorphous movement-type party, and the nation".<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xeFNV40_EUAC&pg=PA65&dq=ultranationalism+authoritarian&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi20tfP0rnaAhWLOsAKHQhhB7wQ6AEIWDAI#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Politics of National Minority Participation in Post-communist Europe'']. ''EastWest Institute''. p.65. Section author - Janusz Bugajski. Book edited by Johnathan P.Stein. Published by M.E. Sharpe. Published in New York in 2000. Retrieved via Google Books.</ref>
[[Roger Griffin]] asserts that ultranationalism is essentially [[Racism|racist]] and is known to legitimise itself "through deeply mythicized narratives of past cultural or political periods of historical greatness or of old scores to settle against alleged enemies". It can also draw on "vulgarized forms of physical anthropology, genetics and [[eugenics]] to rationalize ideas of national superiority and destiny, of degeneracy and subhumanness".<ref>{{cite book|title=World fascism: a historical encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dDYRAQAAMAAJ&q=%22%22through+deeply+mythicized+narratives+of+past+cultural+or+political+periods%22&dq=%22%22through+deeply+mythicized+narratives+of+past+cultural+or+political+periods%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjLpMWk1efZAhWF7lMKHSJqCZoQ6AEIKTAA|year=2006|page=452}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Eternal_return_(Eliade)|Eternal return]] *[[Palingenetic ultranationalism]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Extremism]] [[Category:Nationalism]]
{{politics-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; remove 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{pp-30-500|small=yes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} [[Image:Unrecognized Bedouin village.jpg|thumb|General view of one of the Unrecognized [[Bedouin]] villages in the [[Negev Desert]] of [[Israel]], January 2008]] '''Unrecognized Bedouin villages in Israel''' are rural [[Israeli Bedouins|Bedouin]] communities in the [[Negev]] and the [[Galilee]] which the [[Israeli government]] does not recognize as legal. Often they are referred to as "unrecognized villages".
==General data==
===Number of the villages=== The exact number of unrecognized villages is unknown. Different bodies use different definitions of the term "village". As a result, numbers offered by them differ, but there is an increase in the last decade, in spite of a slow recognition process of some of these communities.
According to Maha Qupty, representing the Bedouin advocacy organization RCUV, in 2004 there were 45 unrecognized Bedouin villages in the Negev.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.hic-net.org/document.php?pid=2670 |title=Bedouin Unrecognized Villages of the Negev |access-date=15 July 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308045459/http://www.hic-net.org/document.php?pid=2670 |archive-date=8 March 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> According to the [[Human Rights Watch]] report based upon the 2006 statistics offered by the [[Adva Center]],<ref name= "Swirski">Shlomo Swirski and Yael Hasson, "[http://www.adva.org/uploaded/NegevEnglishSummary.pdf Invisible Citizens: Israeli Government Policy Toward the Negev Bedouin]", "Adva Center – Information on Equality and Social Justice in Israel", February 2006</ref> approximately half of Bedouin citizens of Israel (85,000 out of 170,000) live in 39 such villages.<ref name="hrw.org">{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/node/62284/section/4|title=Off the Map|work=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref>
According to another Bedouin advocacy organization The Association of Forty, in 2013 there were about 92 unrecognized villages in Israel, 59 of them were Bedouin villages in the Negev.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}}
According to the head of the Bedouin Administration, [[Ya'akov Katz (politician born 1951)|Yaakov Katz]], and geographer [[Arnon Soffer]], in the Negev area alone, there were about 1000 illegal Bedouin concentrations with over 64,000 homes in 2011,<ref>Prof.Arnon Soffer, [http://web.hevra.haifa.ac.il/~ch-strategy/index.php?page=news&id=51 Government resolution regarding the Bedouin dating January 27, 2013]</ref><ref name="sof-a">Arnon Soffer, [http://www.inn.co.il/News/News.aspx/217597 Bedouin coming to Tel Aviv], [[Arutz Sheva|Channel 7]], 29 March 2011</ref> with about 2200-2000 new buildings adding every year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iba.org.il/ibadoc/?entity=746241&type=1&topic=167|title=IBADOC - The IBA Channel 1 Documentaries Dept :: הערוץ הראשון מחלקת תעודה - מבט שני - "מדינת נודדים"|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> For comparison, in 2008 the [[Goldberg Commission]] stated that there were 50,000 illegal buildings in the Negev, and about 1,500 to 2,000 more were built every year.<ref>Aviad Glickman, [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3637006,00.html Report: State should recognize Bedouin villages], [[Ynetnews]], 11 December 2008</ref>
Testifying before the Goldberg Committee in 2010, Israeli right-wing NGO [[Regavim (NGO)|Regavim]] reported 2,100 separate concentrations in Negev of 3–400 constructions each, covering over 800,000 [[dunam]]s.<ref>Ari Briggs, [http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Op-Ed-Contributors/Tower-and-Stockade-settlements-Version-20 Tower and Stockade settlements – Version 2.0], [[Jerusalem Post]] op-ed, 5 September 2012</ref><ref name="pitron">[http://www.regavim.org.il/images/files/yeshpitaron_ivrit.pdf The Regavim movement has a solution], Regavim, 1 January 2011</ref>
===Size of the area=== According to the [[Israel Land Administration]], Negev Bedouin claim area 12 times bigger than that of Tel Aviv.<ref name="MMI" />
According to Prof. Sofer, the Bedouin make up about 2% of the [[Population of Israel|Israeli population]], but the unrecognized Bedouin communities spread on a vast territory and occupy more than 10 percent of Israel – north and east to [[Be'er Sheva]]. According to him, the Negev Bedouin also started to settle west of Be'er Sheva and close to [[Mount Hebron]]. Their communities spread south to [[Dimona]] and towards the [[Judean Desert]]. They occupy large spaces near [[Retamim]] and [[Revivim]] and get close to the [[Gaza Strip]], occupy land in the central Negev near [[Mitzpe Ramon]], and even close to the central area. In 2010 alone about 66 illegal Bedouin settlements were established in the area of [[Rehovot]] and [[Rishon LeZion]].<ref name="shfela">Regev Goldman, [http://www.nrg.co.il/online/54/ART2/133/497.html Lowland Bedouin invaders? War here]. [[Nrg Maariv#Online version|NRG]], 02.01.2012</ref><ref name="bringer">Gil Bringer, [http://data.jsc1.org/pr/articles/GilBringer.bedwim.pdf Solution for every invader]. [[Makor Rishon]], 15 April 2011</ref><ref name="iba">Prof. Arnon Sofer, [http://web.hevra.haifa.ac.il/~ch-strategy/images/publications/goldberg_commission.pdf Following the Goldberg Committee. Did Israel lose the northern Negev], Chaikin Geostrategy, March 2009, [[University of Haifa]]</ref> According to Arnon Sofer, the illegal Bedouin expansion continues rapidly in all directions and occupies spaces that Israel did not know before.<ref name="shomer" /><ref name="hene">Uri Hudi, [http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000707072 Arnon Sofer: Bedouin Arab communities and strangle the country], 15 December 2011, Globes</ref>
===Number of residents=== Between 1994 and 2007, Israel recognized 21 Arab townships with a similar illegal status until then. In the Galilee, most of the illegal villages were regulated and recognized, and from a population of 90,000 Bedouin in the north, a few hundred still live in unrecognized villages.<ref name="shomer">Prof. Arnon Sofer, [http://www.shomer-israel.org/images/stories/doc/arnon1.pdf Because of lack of governance the new guard is born], March 2011, On new guard</ref> In the south, it is estimated that about 90,000 residents live in unrecognized Bedouin villages; these Bedouin comprise 45% of the total Bedouin population.<ref>According to a survey of Association of Forty</ref>
===Status=== The unrecognized villages were built without official permission (this is why they are not recognized by the state) and thus remain ineligible for municipal services, such as connection to the electrical grid, water mains or trash-pickup, and they cannot elect government representatives. They are scattered all over the Northern Negev and often are situated adjacent to military fire zones, [[natural reserve]]s, [[landfill]]s, etc.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Manski|first=Rebecca|title=A Desert Mirage: The Rising Role of US Money in Negev Development|journal=News From Within|date=October–November 2006|volume= XXII| issue = 8|url=http://www.alternativenews.org/english/index.php/component/content/article/100-special-project/news-from-within/749-news-from-within-vol-xxii-no-8-october-november-2006-749|accessdate=4 December 2013}}</ref> For example, the unrecognized Bedouin village of [[Wadi al-Na'am]] is surrounded by an IDF munitions factory and military fire zone, the Efrat Oil Terminal – an oil-storage site, the [[Israel Electric Corporation]] and [[Mekorot]] – the national water carrier site.<ref name="Am">Am Johal, [http://www.caiaweb.org/old-site/files/johal-negev.pdf "Powerless" Bedouin Village Still Seeking Health Care]</ref>
According to a report by the Israeli NGO Adva Center, "The [[Negev Bedouin|Bedouin]] living in the Negev constitute the only group of Arab citizens of Israel that still has a large-scale hold on the land, a hold that the state officially denies in principle, while recognizing in practice."<ref name="Swirski"/><ref name="hrw.org"/>
According to the [[Israel Land Administration]] (2007), some 60 per cent of the Negev Bedouin lived in seven permanent state-planned townships, such as [[Rahat]], [[Tel as-Sabi]], [[Shaqib al-Salam]] (Segev Shalom), [[Ar'arat an-Naqab]], [[Kuseife]], [[Lakiya]] and [[Hura]], while the rest (40 per cent) – "in illegal homes spread over hundreds of thousands of dunams".<ref name="MMI">[http://www.mmi.gov.il/static/HanhalaPirsumim/Beduin_information.pdf Bedouin information], ILA, 2007</ref>
Since 2003 a number of previously illegal Bedouin communities were recognized by the state (such as [[Al-Sayyid, Israel|al-Sayyid]]), and several new ones were built (such as [[Tirabin al-Sana]]) totaling 12 (not including the previous seven townships).<ref>Patricia Golan, [http://b1.jpost.com/JerusalemReport/Israel/Article.aspx?id=275259 Built on sand], Jerusalem Report, 26 June 2012</ref> They were united under [[Abu Basma Regional Council]] that was split on 5 November 2012 into two newly created bodies: [[Neve Midbar Regional Council]] and [[al-Kasom Regional Council]].<ref>[http://abubasma.org.il/index.php?m=ar&artd=6282 Information for the citizens] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130821123651/http://abubasma.org.il/index.php?m=ar&artd=6282 |date=21 August 2013 }}, Abu Basma Regional Council official site (Hebrew)</ref> As of July 2013, there are no updated official statistics on the number of Bedouin living outside the government-[[Planned community|planned]] and officially recognized communities.
==History== {{Main|Negev Bedouin}}
===The Ottoman empire=== During the 19th century and the first half of the 20th century, the semi-arid region of the Negev was inhabited mostly by [[semi-nomadic]] Bedouin tribes.<ref name="manski1">Rebecca Manski, [Criminalizing Self-Subsistence], ''News from Within", Summer 2006</ref>
In 1858 the Turks enacted [[Tanzimat|a law]] stating that all landowners names must be officially documented as a means of regulating matters relating to land in the Ottoman Empire. Most of the land in the Negev was classified as muwat (dead land, wasteland unsuitable for cultivation).
The Bedouin did not create a written record of their connection to the land, and some argue that even opposed to it, since it would make them subject to the [[Ottoman empire]], what would require them to pay taxes and serve in the Ottoman army. Also, when the publication of the [[Ottoman Land Code of 1858|Ottoman Lands Ordinance]], the Negev area had no permanent settlement.
By the year 1896 Negev Bedouin lived in almost complete freedom. The Ottomans were not interested and did not intervene in the Negev and the Bedouins. According to Yosef Ben-Dor, only after a tribal war, the Turkish government marked tribal boundaries, but did not give the Bedouins in this agreement "ownership" of tribal territorial lands.<ref name="Goldberg">[http://www.landpedia.org/landdoc/Analytical_materials/Goldberg_recommendations-english.pdf Goldberg Commission's recommendations], RCUV, p.6</ref>
===British Mandate=== The British government adopted the Ottoman land laws, and added to them the Land Ordinance, intended to prevent squatting and recognition of unauthorized takeover of land.
In 1921, the government of the [[Mandatory Palestine|British Mandate]] issued an order for all the Negev residents to register their land. According to the Land Ordinance of 1921, any Bedouin who cultivated and improved a "mewat" (dead) land received a confirmation of ownership on that same land. Although the Bedouin were granted with a special extension of two-month to register their land, they have never done so, and the land remained unregistered.<ref Name="bendavid">Joseph son of David. [Bust Negev Bedouin, Jews, land, fresh: Center for Arab society in Israel], 1996</ref>
Mandate authorities also conducted a preliminary registration of land and since 1934 began to collect land taxes. Mandatory maps show the location of the Bedouin tribes, however, the maps never marked the boundaries of each tribe.
The 1947 report of the [[United Nations Special Committee on Palestine]] estimated the number of bedouins in the Beersheba district to be about 90,000.<ref>[https://unispal.un.org/unispal.nsf/0/07175de9fa2de563852568d3006e10f3 UNSCOP Report, Vol II.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120610173759/http://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/07175DE9FA2DE563852568D3006E10F3 |date=10 June 2012 }}, Chapter 2, Para. 21.</ref> In preparation for a 1946 census of Palestine that was never carried out, the British government surveyed all the tribes ''in situ'' and concluded that the number of bedouin in the Beersheba district was about 92,000 out of 127,000 in the whole country.<ref name=AAC1432/> It also reported that they cultivated about two million dunums of cereal land and that aerial photographs of the northern Beersheva taken by the Royal Air Force revealed the existence of 3,389 houses and 8,722 tents."<ref name=AAC1432>Ad Hoc Committee on the Palestine Question, Report of Sub-committee 2, November 11, 1947, [http://domino.un.org/pdfs/AAC1432.pdf UN Doc A/AC.14/32], pages 40 and 65.</ref> The same figure of two million dunams appeared in a 1944/5 book of [[Yosef Weitz]], but in contrast "Shimoni and Tartakover estimate the area cultivated by Bedouin in the Negev at only 60,000 dunam."<ref>[http://www.landpedia.org/landdoc/Analytical_materials/Goldberg_recommendations-english.pdf Goldberg Committee recommendations], quoting a 1982 paper of Aharon Zohar.</ref>
According to Sasson Bar Zvi, a cultural researcher of the Negev Bedouin, and Arie Efrat who served as director for the Arab villages in the south, the lack of water in the Negev area did not allow its residents to revive the land and therefore they preferred nomadic life and shepherding to an organized and rental land cultivation, and this is why the land remained a desolate area.<ref name="psak">[http://weblaw.haifa.ac.il/he/Faculty/Kedar/lecdb/bedouins/387.doc Salim Ali Agdia to Hawashla and others vs. State of Israel], Civil Appeal No. 218\74]</ref>
According to the Bedouin, although they did not document land ownership, the Turkish government and the British recognized the rights of ownership of land in which they roamed, and this recognition was expressed when the Bedouins sold land to the Zionist movement during the British Mandate, and the sales were recognized and recorded in the [[Tapu (Ottoman law)|land registry (Tabu)]]. In contrast, Dr. Yosef Ben-David explains this fact by claiming that the Ottoman and British authorities saw a blessing in transferring land from the Bedouin to the applicant for registration, because they will be likely to use land intensively, without the authorities taking into consideration any legal rights the Bedouins had to the land recognized by either government.<ref name = "bendavid "/>
Furthermore, Jews who dealt with redemption of lands in the establishment of Israel gave [[ex gratia]] funds to the Bedouin to enable the rapid registration of Israel lands in the land registry, and not because legal recognition of ownership of the Bedouin on the land. Since the beginning of the 1930s and until the establishment of the State of Israel, the Bedouin sold almost 765,000 dunams of land, of which about 180,000 sold to [[JNF]] representatives and about 45,000 dunams to private Jews. The rest 545,000 dunams, were sold mainly to Arab peasants from the Gaza Strip.<ref name="jes">Daniel Center for Strategic Dialogue, [http://www.fnst-jerusalem.org/beduim.pdf Negev Bedouin strategic challenge to Israel], [[Netanya Academic College]], January 2013</ref>
===Israel=== [[Image:Greenwashing - the old way of life, trashed.JPG|thumb|180px|Goats grazing beneath garbage bins in [[Tel Sheva]]]] During the [[1948 Arab–Israeli War]], the Negev region saw harsh battles between the newly created [[Israel Defense Forces]] and the [[Egyptian army]]. In the aftermath of the war, most of the Negev was included within the borders of the newly established [[State of Israel]]. Censuses before and after the war indicate that about 80% of the Bedouin population left the Negev to areas that remained under Arab rule.<ref name=goldberg>[http://www.moch.gov.il/SiteCollectionDocuments/odot/doch_goldberg/Doch_Vaada_Shofet_Goldberg.pdf Report of the Commission to Propose a Policy for Arranging Bedouin Settlement in the Negev], a.k.a. the Goldberg Report, pp. 6–13 (Hebrew version)</ref>
The Israeli authorities' treatment of the Bedouin population was ambivalent. On the one hand, the Bedouin were considered loyal to the new state, and some of them even volunteered to serve in the IDF. On the other hand, Israel saw the Negev as its "[[hinterland]]", being sparsely populated and as the [[West Bank]] came under Jordanian rule. The policy eventually adopted was forcing the Bedouin to concentrate in an area of 1,100 km<sup>2</sup>, that has become known as the ''Siyagh'' (Arabic for "the permitted area") region, stretching between the West Bank border to the north-east, [[Be'er Sheva]] to the south-west and Arad to the south. All the Bedouin remaining under Israeli rule were granted Israeli citizenship, but the ''Siyagh'' region was placed under martial law until 1966, like many other mostly Arab-populated areas in Israel at the time.<ref name=goldberg/><ref name=Fridman>{{cite web|url=http://www.localeconomyseminar.net/?p=88|author=Dor Fridman|title=About the Negev Bedouins|publisher=LocalEconomySeminar|access-date=21 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120705070215/http://www.localeconomyseminar.net/?p=88|archive-date=5 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This was the time when most of the unrecognized villages of today were established.{{clarify|date=December 2013}}
The Bedouin claims for ownership on lands in the Negev were, by and large, rejected by the Israeli authorities, on the pretext that the ownership is not appropriately [[Tapu (Ottoman law)|documented]] or that the lands claimed are not eligible to [[Private ownership of land|private ownership]]. Both Bedouin citizens and state authorities agree that only a small minority of the claim can be backed with full legally valid documentation, however the Bedouin claimants demand that their traditional ties with the lands, namely the fact that they de facto held the rights on these lands without objection on behalf of the former Ottoman or British authorities, be recognized by the State of Israel as ownership.
Implementing her land policies, Israel started to rely on the [[Ottoman Land Code of 1858]], the only preceding law frame in the region. According to these regulations, lands that were not registered as of private ownership, were considered state lands. Israel relied mainly on [[Tapu (Ottoman law)|Tabu]] recordings. Most of the Bedouin land fell under the Ottoman class of 'non-workable' (mawat) land and thus belonged to the state under Ottoman law. Eventually, Israel nationalized most of the Negev lands, using The Land Rights Settlement Ordinance from 1969.<ref name="Fridman"/><ref name = Kurt>{{cite journal | author = Kurt Goering | title = Israel and the Bedouin of the Negev | journal = Journal of Palestine Studies | volume =9 | issue = 1 | pages = 3–20 | date = Autumn 1979 | doi = 10.1525/jps.1979.9.1.00p0173n }}</ref><ref name="TobiFenster">(Hebrew) Dr. Tobi Fenster, A summary stance paper on Bedouin land issues, written for "Sikkuy – for equal opportunity"</ref> [[File:Hura's downtown.jpg|thumb|left|[[Hura]] downtown]] In order to reinforce the invisible Siyag fence and sedentarize the Bedouin, the State employed a reining mechanism, the Black Goat Law of 1950. The Black Goat Law curbed grazing so as to prevent land erosion, prohibiting the grazing of goats outside recognized land holdings.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} Since few Bedouin territorial claims were recognized, most grazing was thereby rendered illegal.
Most Bedouin who had the option, preferred not to register their lands under the Ottoman rule as this would mean being taxed without representation or services. Those whose land claims were recognized found it almost impossible to keep their goats within the periphery of their newly limited range. Into the 1970s and 1980s, only a small portion of the Bedouin were able to continue to graze their goats. Instead of migrating with their goats in search of pasture, the majority of the Bedouin migrated in search of wage-labor.<ref name="manski1" />
In the mid-1970s Israel let the Negev Bedouin register their land claims and issued special certificates that served as the basis for the "right of possession" later granted by the government. Following the signing of the Treaty of Peace with Egypt, it became necessary to move an airport from a [[Sinai peninsula]] to a locality inhabited by some five thousand Bedouin. The government, recognizing these land claim certificates, negotiated with the certificate holders and paid compensation to them. Most moved to Bedouin townships, built houses and established businesses.<ref>Dr. Yosef Ben-David. [https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Society_&_Culture/Bedouin.html The Bedouin in Israel], 1999</ref>
The Israeli government has promoted the [[sedentarization]] of the Bedouin population. In 1963, [[Moshe Dayan]] said: {{cquote|We should transform the Bedouins into an urban [[proletariat]] – in industry, services, construction, and agriculture. 88% of the Israeli population are not farmers, let the Bedouin be like them. Indeed, this will be a radical move which means that the Bedouin would not live on his land with his herds, but would become an urban person who comes home in the afternoon and puts his slippers on. His children will get used to a father who wears pants, without a dagger, and who does not pick out their nits in public. They will go to school, their hair combed and parted. This will be a revolution, but it can be achieved in two generations."|||Israeli General Moshe Dayan to ''Haaretz'', 1963<ref name="manski1" /><ref>Donald Macintyre.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/end-of-the-road-for-the-bedouin-517396.html End of the road for the Bedouin] ''The Independent,'' November 29, 2005</ref>}} Dayan added, "Without coercion but with governmental direction ... this phenomenon of the Bedouins will disappear".
The Bedouin communities in the Negev, many unrecognised by the Israeli government, were classified as "open areas" during the [[2014 Israel–Gaza conflict]] and so their 200,000 residents did not have warning sirens or anti-rocket protection.<ref>{{cite news | author1 = Jack Khoury | author2 = Shirly Seidler | author3 = Gili Cohen | last-author-amp = yes | title = Bedouin in south unprotected from rocket fire | newspaper = Haaretz | date = July 16, 2014 |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/1.605416}}</ref>
==State treatment==
===Arrangement attempts=== In the 1970s Israel collected all the "claims of ownership" in the Negev, without permits and without proof, for the purpose of registering these claims. However, the Bedouin saw the state registry as a recognition for their claims. More than 3,000 ownership claims were filed for the land sized over 800,000 dunams, which includes nearly the whole area between [[Be'er Sheva]] – [[Arad (Israel)|Arad]] – [[Dimona]] and other areas throughout the entire Negev, including those that belong to kibbutzim and cities.
In the first years of the arrangement, anyone demanding area of over 400 [[dunam]]s had the opportunity to get 20% of the land from the [[Land Registry]], and for the rest of the area they would receive financial compensation. Anyone who demanded less than 400 dunams, had received only monetary compensation. In addition, the state of Israel compensated the Bedouin for any building, tin shack, barn or even a tree that the Bedouin placed and the government removed. The compensation value was even higher than the property's value in the market. In 20% of the claims the state has reached a settlement with the Bedouin.<ref name="MMI" />
At the same time, some Bedouin tried to claim the land ownership in the court, despite the May 1984 [[Supreme Court of Israel|Supreme Court]] [[precedent]] ruling of Justice Avraham Halima, stating that Bedouin are [[nomad]]s by definition and thus cannot have any ownership of land.<ref>While the state is the owner of all the mawat land in the Negev as defined in the 1858 Ottoman lands ordinance and the 1921 British lands ordinance, unless the Bedouin have legal title deeds (Supreme Court, C.A. 218/74)</ref> In all 80 cases in which Bedouin claims arrived to court, the judges ruled in favor of the state, since there was no document proving Bedouin land ownership. According to recent data submitted to the [[Goldberg Commission]] by the Bedouin Administration in July 2008, 2840 claims remained, whose overall area is 571,186 dunams.<ref>According to claims officer attorney Rami Damari. Goldberg committee report, [http://www.landpedia.org/landdoc/Analytical_materials/Goldberg_recommendations-english.pdf A land settlement], No. 34, p.15</ref>
===Planned townships=== Dealing with the problem of the Negev Bedouin, between 1968 and 1989 Israel built seven planned townships especially for the Bedouin in the attempt to urbanize them.<ref name="MMI" /> The largest Bedouin locality in Israel, the city of [[Rahat]], was established in 1971. Other townships include [[Tel as-Sabi]] (Tel Sheva) (established in 1969), [[Shaqib al-Salam]] (Segev Shalom) in 1979, [[Ar'arat an-Naqab]] (Ar'ara BaNegev) and [[Kuseife]] in 1982, [[Lakiya]] in 1985 and [[Hura]] in 1989.<ref name=Swirski/><ref name=autogenerated4>Rebecca Manski. [http://www.bustan.org/subject.asp?id=25 "THE NATURE OF ENVIRONMENTAL INJUSTICE IN BEDOUIN URBAN TOWNSHIPS: THE END OF SELF-SUBSISTENCE"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003220015/http://www.bustan.org/subject.asp?id=25 |date=3 October 2011 }}; Life and Environment, 2006 (translation from Hebrew)</ref><ref name="jkcook.net">[[Jonathan Cook]].[http://www.jkcook.net/Articles2/0143.htm "Bedouin in the Negev face new 'transfer"]; MERIP, 10 May 2003</ref>
Since grazing has been severely restricted, and the Bedouin rarely receive permits to engage in [[subsistence agriculture]],<ref>Aref Abu-Rabia. ''The Negev Bedouin and Livestock Rearing: Social, Economic, and Political Aspects,'' Oxford, 1994, pp. 28, 36, 38 (in a rare move, the ILA has leased annually [[JNF]]-owned land in [[Besor]] Valley (Wadi Shallala) to Bedouins)</ref> few of the Bedouin in unrecognized villages consider the urban townships as desirable form of settlement.<ref>Jonathan Cook. [http://www.jkcook.net/Articles2/0213.htm "Making the land without a people"]; ''Al-Ahram Weekly,'' 26 Aug-1 Sep 2004</ref><ref name="McGreal">Chris McGreal.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2003/feb/27/israel "Bedouin feel the squeeze as Israel resettles the Negev desert: Thousands displaced from ancient homeland"]; ''The Guardian,'' Thursday 27 February 2003</ref> Denied access to their former sources of sustenance via grazing restrictions, severed from the possibility of access to water, electricity, roads, education, and health care in the unrecognized villages, tens of thousands of Bedouin citizens of Israel resettled in the townships.<ref name="jkcook.net"/>
According to [[Ben-Gurion University of the Negev|Ben Gurion University]]'s Negev Center for Regional Development, these first towns were poorly planned and were lacking business districts or industrial zones;<ref name="lithwick1">Harvey Lithwick, Ismael Abu Saad, Kathleen Abu-Saad, Merkaz HaNegev LeFitu'ah Ezori and Merkaz LeHeker HaHevra HaBeduit VeHitpathuta (Israel). "A Preliminary Evaluation of the Negev Bedouin Experience of Urbanization: Findings of the Urban Household Survey"; Negev Center for Regional Development, 2004</ref> as Harvey Lithwick of the Negev Center for Regional Development explains: "the major failure was a lack of an economic rationale for the towns".<ref>Harvey Lithwick, "An Urban Development Strategy for the Negev's Bedouin Community", The Center for Bedouin Studies and Development, Ben Gurion University (2000)</ref>
===Abu Basma Regional Council=== {{Main|Abu Basma Regional Council}} [[File:AlSayyid school4.jpg|thumb|left|A newly built school in [[Al-Sayyid, Israel|al-Sayyid]]]] On 29 September 2003 Israeli [[Cabinet of Israel|government]] has adapted a new "Abu Basma Plan" (Resolution 881), according to which a new regional council was formed, unifying a number of unrecognized Bedouin settlements – [[Abu Basma Regional Council]].<ref>[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1196847418880&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/Printer Beduin in Limbo] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130706010434/http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1196847418880&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/Printer |date=6 July 2013 }} The Jerusalem Post, 24 December 2007</ref> This resolution also regarded the need to establish seven new Bedouin settlements in the Negev,<ref>[http://www.abrahamfund.org/main/siteNew/index.php?page=115&action=sidLink&stId=903 Government resolutions passed in recent years regarding the Arab population of Israel] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207082421/http://www.abrahamfund.org/main/siteNew/index.php?page=115&action=sidLink&stId=903 |date=7 February 2012 }}, Abraham Fund Initiative</ref> literally meaning the official recognition of unrecognized settlements, providing them with a municipal status and consequently with all the basic services and infrastructure. The council was established by the [[Israeli Ministry of Interior|Interior Ministry]] on 28 January 2004.<ref name=MJB>[http://brookdale-en1.pionet.com/files/word-documents/Abu_Basma_visit_highlights.doc The Bedouin Population in Transition: Site Visit to Abu Basma Regional Council] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928165539/http://brookdale-en1.pionet.com/files/word-documents/Abu_Basma_visit_highlights.doc |date=28 September 2007 }} Myers-JDC-Brookdale Institute, 28 June 2005</ref>
Moreover, Israel is currently building or enlarging some 13 towns and cities in the Negev.<ref name="MMI" /> According to the general planning, all of them will be fully equipped with the relevant infrastructure: schools, medical clinics, postal offices, etc. and they also will have electricity, running water and waste control. Several new industrial zones are planned, some are already being constructed, like [[Idan haNegev]] on the suburbs of Rahat.<ref>[http://bns-en.com/en-us/39/41/ Idan Hanegev Industrial Park]</ref> It will have a hospital and a new campus inside.<ref>Itamar Eichner, [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4210642,00.html Harvard University makes aliyah], ynet, 1 April 2012</ref>
===Recognition vs demolition=== Israel is trying to solve the problem of unrecognized villages by attracting the scattered communities into government-planned townships and villages offering land plots at low prices<ref>In [[Hura]] an 800 square meters land lot costs 60–65 thousand shekels ($15–16 thousand) for clan members or 22 thousand shekels ($5.5 thousand) for a demobilized soldier. [http://abualkian.com/index.php/clan-members-transition-to-the-village-of-houra Clan members’ transition to the village of Houra]</ref> and as an extreme measure – following the court order and all the legal procedure – demolishes houses built without state's permission on what it considers to be state lands.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/apr/01/israelandthepalestinians1 Rory McCarthy, "Nomadic bedouin fight to survive in the village which does not exist: Israel accused of discriminating against Negev desert clans"], ''The Guardian'', 1 April 2008; [http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/925222.html "Bedouin village faces demolition due to new Jewish neighborhood"], Zafrir Rinat, ''Ha'aretz'', 18 November 2007; [https://www.hrw.org/english/docs/2008/03/31/isrlpa18387.htm "Israel: End Systematic Bias Against Bedouin"], [[Human Rights Watch]], 31 March 2008</ref> The unrecognized villages are not accurately marked on any official maps. [[Image:Unrecognized demolished house2.jpg|thumb|Demolished house in the unrecognized Bedouin village of Alsara, January 2008]] A number of villages has been recognized in the 2000s as a part of creation of the [[Abu Basma Regional Council]]. In 2009 the [[Goldberg Commission]] recommended that most of the 46 unrecognised villages east of [[Highway 40 (Israel)|Route 40]] should be recognised and their 50,000 illegal structures be legalized.
In 2010, Israeli authorities demolished the unrecognized village of [[al-Araqeeb]]. Since then it has been rebuilt and destroyed several dozen times (September 2012).<ref>[http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/06/13/220418.html Palestinian villagers demand Guinness entry for demolition record], [[Al Arabiya]], 13 June 2012</ref> The matter of land ownership in the area of al-Araqeeb was raised in court when several members of al-Uqbi family filed a suit against the State claiming ownership of land. After a thorough examination of this case involving leading experts in the field, in March 2012 came a court ruling in favor of the State.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://old.justice.gov.il/NR/rdonlyres/0FA805C1-9BCC-4FB0-8F1E-47CC9E869EC5/37796/ElUqbiEniglishfinal.pdf |title=Full text of court judgement |access-date=18 October 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202230550/http://old.justice.gov.il/NR/rdonlyres/0FA805C1-9BCC-4FB0-8F1E-47CC9E869EC5/37796/ElUqbiEniglishfinal.pdf |archive-date=2 December 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Judge Sarah Dovrat said that the land was not "assigned to the plaintiffs, nor held by them under conditions required by law," and that they still had to "prove their rights to the land by proof of its registration in the [[Tapu (Ottoman law)|Tabu]]" (Israel Lands Authority). The judge noted that the Bedouin knew they were supposed to register but did not.<ref>Jerusalem Post, "Court rejects 6 Bedouin Negev land lawsuits", 19 March 2012. [http://www.jpost.com/NationalNews/Article.aspx?ID=262501&R=R1]</ref>
===Prawer plan=== In September 2011, the Israeli government approved a five-year [[economic development]] plan called the [[Prawer Commission|''Prawer plan'']].<ref name="Prawer">[http://www.pmo.gov.il/English/MediaCenter/Spokesman/Pages/spokenegev110911.aspx Cabinet Approves Plan to Provide for the Status of Communities in, and the Economic Development of, the Bedouin Sector in the Negev], PMO official site, 11 September 2012</ref> One of its implications is a relocation of some 30.000–40.000 Negev Bedouin from areas not recognized by the government to government-approved townships.<ref>Al Jazeera, 13 September 2011, [http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2011/09/2011912151231223454.html ''Bedouin transfer plan shows Israel's racism'']</ref><ref>Guardian, 3 November 2011, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/03/bedouin-plight-traditions-threat-israel ''Bedouin's plight: "We want to maintain our traditions. But it's a dream here"'']</ref>
According to the PMO official press release, the plan is based on four main principles: # Providing for the status of Bedouin communities in the Negev; # Economic development for the Negev's Bedouin population; # Resolving claims over [[land ownership]]; and # Establishing a mechanism for binding, implementation and [[enforcement]], as well as timetables.<ref name="Prawer" /> [[File:Tirabin al-Sana mosque.jpg|thumb|left|280px|Tirabin al-Sana's mosque (its [[dome]] taken from mosque in the previous [[Tarabin bedouin|Tarabin]] tribe residence place next to [[Omer, Israel|Omer]])]] When the cabinet approved it, simultaneously it also approved a NIS 1.2 billion economic development program for Bedouin Negev whose main purpose is to support the Bedouin women and youth in the fields of employment since they will contribute to the increased economic growth of the entire Bedouin community. Much of the approved funds will be allocated for the development of [[industrial park|industrial zones]], establishment of [[employment center]]s and [[Professional development|professional training]].
According to the Prawer plan, the present Bedouin communities will undergo a comprehensive planning process. The existing communities will be expanded, some unrecognized communities will be recognized and start to receive [[public services]], while their infrastructure will be renewed. All these changes will be done in the framework of the Beer Sheva District masterplan. It's important to note that the nature of these future communities, whether agricultural, rural, suburban or urban will be decided in full cooperation with the local Bedouin. For those of them who are to be relocated, 2/3 of them will receive a new residence nearby.<ref name="Prawer" />
The Prawer plan seeks to give an answer to numerous land claims filed by the Bedouin. It will offers significant compensation in land and funds – 50% of the claim (currently it's only 20% offered), while each claim will be dealt in a unified and transparent way provided by law.<ref name="Prawer" />
Nevertheless, exists harsh criticism of the Prawer plan. Critics say that it will turn Bedouin dispossession into law<ref>[http://www.alternativenews.org/english/index.php/component/content/article/28-news/4109-bill-will-turn-bedouin-dispossession-into-israeli-law Bill will turn Bedouin dispossession into Israeli law] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424114822/http://www.alternativenews.org/english/index.php/component/content/article/28-news/4109-bill-will-turn-bedouin-dispossession-into-israeli-law |date=24 April 2012 }}, Alternative news, 2 January 2012</ref><ref>Neve Gordon, [http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2012/04/2012421020291808.html Uprooting 30,000 Bedouin in Israel], Al Jazeera, 3 April 2012</ref> and come to a conclusion that relocation of the Bedouin will be compelled. Some even speak about ethnic cleansing.<ref>David Sheen, [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/opinion/the-real-social-justice-movement-1.394922 ], [[Haaretz]], 11 November</ref> As a result, these remarks provoked heavy criticism of the plan by the European Parliament.<ref>Haaretz, 8 July 2012, [http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/european-parliament-condemns-israel-s-policy-toward-bedouin-population-1.449687 ''European Parliament condemns Israel's policy toward Bedouin population'']</ref>
There are several examples of success in this matter: after a number of complicated agreements with the state all of the Bedouin of [[Tarabin bedouin|Tarabin]] clan moved into a township built for them – [[Tirabin al-Sana]]. Following negotiations, the Bedouin of al-[['Azazme]] clan will take part in the planning of a new quarter that will be erected for them to west of [[Segev Shalom]] township, cooperating with The Authority for the Regulation of Bedouin Settlement in the Negev.<ref>Yanir Yagna, [http://www.haaretz.co.il/news/education/1.1745154 For the first time: Bedouin to take part in planning of their new neighborhood] (Hebrew), [[Haaretz]], 1 July 2012</ref>
===Hindrances for the arrangement=== One of the main hindrances in finding a solution for the illegal settlement is the [[Bedouin systems of justice|Bedouin Tribal Law]] which states that one should not settle on a land that other Bedouin claims to own it.<ref name="sof">Arnon Sofer, [http://www.inn.co.il/News/News.aspx/217597 Bedouin coming to Tel Aviv], [[Arutz Sheva|Channel 7]], 29 March 2011</ref>
According to the head of the unrecognized villages – Hussein Abu Pia testifying in front of the Goldberg Committee members: "If the land is in a one Bedouin's claim of ownership, the other will not come close. He would not dare. He will prefer to live in a cave, instead of approaching the land".<ref name="kalm1">Kalman Libeskind [http://www.nrg.co.il/online/54/ART2/133/497.html Negev going lost: How the state failed to treat the Bedouins of the South]. [[Nrg Maariv#Online version|NRG]], 16 July 2010</ref>
There is a common phenomenon of the Bedouin who receive compensation and new homes in legal towns, yet return and construct again in state lands thus not fulfilling the agreements signed with the government. They were paid a compensation for relinquishing their claims to the state, but still claim ownership on the land to other Bedouin, so the problem remains unsolved. The town of [[Kuseife]], for example is built almost entirely on lands claimed by different tribes, and thus two-thirds of the city is empty.<ref name="kalm1" />
Bedouin lands' claims don't take into account central planning issues. When agreement made, the Bedouin receive 20%–62% of the land they claimed. These lands are speckled with those registered in the Land Registry as belonging to other Bedouin. As a result, state encounters a serious problem developing Negev. Due to this issue, it is not possible to develop the eastern part of the [[Be'er Sheva]] metropolitan.<ref name="lirit">[[Prawer Commission|Ehud Prawer]] and Lirit Srafis, [http://www.dukium.org/user_uploads/pdfs/%EB%F0%F1%20%E4%F8%F6%EC%E9%E4%20%F1%E5%F4%E9.pdf Negev Bedouin, policies, problems and recommendations], January 2006, National Security Council {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
According to government sources, another hindrance in the arrangement attempts is the absence of deadline for the negotiations.<ref Name="bringer" /> According to Prof. Sofer: "Bedouin always say 'no' to attempts to reach a compromise with them about the lands that they claim, because they know that every 'no' only strengthens them. One of the main problems in this program is lack of a final date. The state should set a date by which it is willing to give increased compensation for those who erase the claim of ownership, and from there on – no more compromise and a confrontation is needed even if it will come at a high price."<ref Name="bringer" />
According to officials involved in negotiations, there is a lack of consistency in granting compensations. The Bedouin Administration manages negotiations with each tribe or family separately, soo the compensation size differs. Conciliatory families receive lower compensation, while the recalcitrant families' compensation is higher (a good example is the evacuation of the Bedouin [[Tarabin bedouin|Tarabin]] from the outskirts of [[Omer, Israel|Omer]]). The state also offers higher compensations to families with a leader that the government needs him by their side, or to families that claim land ownership in the areas of special importance to the state.<ref name="kalm1" /> One of the reasons for the lack of uniformity is the crisis of the Bedouin community leadership. Currently there is no agreed Bedouin leadership to resolve the land issue, and the Bedouin refuse to place representatives on the ground, so there is no authority to represent all of the claimants.<ref name="kalm1" />
Another factor hindering the arrangement is tribal feud. According to one of the negotiators, attorney Itay Bar, Southern District Attorney for Civil Affairs, "Sometimes you can not place one Bedouin next to another because his son insulted him 20 years ago".<ref name="kalm1" />
According to Faisal el-Husael, the public representative from the Bedouin inside the Goldberg committee,<ref name="Goldberg" /> often the Bedouin are not willing to relocate to planned towns since they prefer rural settlements to semi-urban townships.<ref name="alhozeil">[http://www.izsvideo.org/videos/full/g151.pdf Protocol of Goldberg Committee for proposing a policy of regulating Bedouin settlement in the Negev], [[Haifa University]], 15 January 2008</ref>
==Features==
===High natural growth=== Illegal villages are a deteriorating problem and one of the reasons is the high population growth. The Negev Bedouin have one of the highest rates of natural growth in the world, standing at 4–5.5% per year,<ref>Evgenia Bystrof, Arnon Soffer, [http://web.hevra.haifa.ac.il/~ch-strategy/images/publications/demography_2007_en.pdf Israel: Demography and density. 2007–2020]. Chaikin Geostrategy, [[University of Haifa]], May 2008, p.27</ref><ref>Avinoam Meir, Dov Barnea, [http://cnp.nonuniv.ox.ac.uk/pdf/NP_journal_back_issues/The_Educational_System_of_the_Israeli_Negev_Bedouin_A_Meir_and_D_Barnea.pdf The educational system of the Israeli Negev Bedouin], p.25</ref> which means doubling the population every 12–15 years.<ref name="MMI" /> So while in 1951 they numbered 12,000, in 1970 – about 25,000, in 1990 – about 87,000 people, and in 2008 – approximately 180,000. In 2020 are expected to reach 400,000.<ref Name="iba" />
In 2008 [[Israel Central Bureau of Statistics]] informed that fertility rate among the Arab population in the south of Israel (primarily Bedouin) dropped from 9 children per woman in 2003 to 7.6 children in 2005,<ref>Shahar Ilan, [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/cbs-reports-drop-in-ultra-orthodox-fertility-rate-1.237112 CBS reports drop in ultra-Orthodox fertility rate], [[Haaretz]], 13 January 2008</ref> but it still remains high relatively to other population groups inside Israel.
The high fertility rate for Bedouin is exacerbated by polygamy (up to 36% of Bedouin men are polygamous)<ref name = "iba" /><ref name="poli">Committee on the status of Women, [https://www.knesset.gov.il/mmm/data/pdf/m01600.pdf Polygamy among the Bedouin population in Israel], Research and Information Center Committee</ref> and illegal infiltration estimated at 16,000 women who had infiltrated for polygamy (until 2004) and were accompanied by their families.<ref name="iba" /><ref>Prof. Arnon Sofer and colonel Gil Shalev, [http://web.hevra.haifa.ac.il/~ch-strategy/images/publications/give_back_palistine_claim.pdf Actual realization of the "right of return" PA], Chaikin Geostrategy, July 2004, on [[University of Haifa]]</ref>
In 2008, Israel together with leading figures in the Bedouin community initiated a state program to address the phenomenon of Bedouin polygamy and its severely harmful implications on family structure.<ref name="Alg">[http://www.algemeiner.com/2013/06/18/israel%E2%80%99s-negev-facing-alarming-changes Israel’s Negev Facing Alarming Changes], [[Algemeiner Journal|Algemeiner]], 18 June 2013</ref>
Bedouin advocates argue that the main reason for the transfer of the Bedouin into townships was demographic.<ref name="alternativenews.org">BUSTAN on the Blueprint; Excerpt of [http://www.alternativenews.org/english/index.php/component/content/article/16-news-from-within/749-news-from-within-vol-xxii-no-8-october-november-2006.html Rebecca Manski, "The Rising Role of American Money in Negev Development"]; ''News from Within,'' October/November 2005)</ref> They note that in 2003, director of the Israeli Population Administration Department, Herzl Gedj, described [[polygamy]] in the Bedouin sector as a "security threat" and advocated various means of reducing the Arab birth rate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merip.org/mero/mero060106.html|title=Middle East Report Online - Middle East Research and Information Project|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> In 2003, [[Shai Hermesh]], the treasurer of the [[Jewish Agency]], told ''[[The Guardian]]'': "We need the Negev for the next generation of Jewish immigrants" and added, "It is not in Israel's interest to have more Palestinians in the Negev."<ref name="McGreal"/> Bedouin rights groups opposed this plan, as they were concerned that the unrecognized villages might be cleared to make way for Jewish development and potentially ignite internal civil strife.<ref name="alternativenews.org"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neohasid.org/negev/resolution|title=NeoHasid.org - Ohalah Resolution on Blueprint Negev|author1=David Seidenberg|author2= Shir-Yaakov Feinstein-Feit|author3= FourWorldsDesign.com|last-author-amp= yes|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref><ref>Daniel Orenstein, [http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/841397.html "When an 'ecological' community is not"], ''Haaretz''</ref><ref>[http://neohasid.org/negev/brous "Brous' Open Letter to the JNF"], ''Baltimore Jewish Times,'' January 2006]</ref>
In October 2011 the government decided to establish seven new agricultural settlements in the area of Mevo'ot Arad. On 14 August 2012, residents of five unrecognized Bedouin villages, along with residents of Arad, the [[Association for Civil Rights in Israel]] (ACRI), [[Bimkom]] – Planners for Planning Rights, and the Negev Coexistence Forum for Civil Equality, petitioned the [[Israeli High Court#High Court of Justice|High Court of Justice]] against the plan saying that it will uproot 800 Bedouin. <ref>[http://www.acri.org.il/en/2012/08/14/acri-petitions-high-court-to-stop-government-plan-to-build-seven-new-settlements-in-around-arad-at-existing-residents-expense/ "ACRI Petitions High Court to Stop Government Plan to Build Seven New Settlements in Around Arad at Existing Residents’ Expense"], Association for Civil Rights in Israel (ACRI), 14 August 2012</ref>
===Acceleration in illegal construction=== Israel has encountered a problem of maintaining law due to uncontrolled illegal construction in the Negev Bedouin dispersed communities.<ref>According to [http://www.landpedia.org/landdoc/Analytical_materials/Goldberg_recommendations-english.pdf Section 67 in Goldberg report]: "These basic norms of adhering to the law have been eroded in the pzura (dispersals), in particular in all matters concerning illegal building which has reached enormous proportions. The Bedouin justify this through the needs of a growing population to have a roof over its head. In the absence of any alternative, and as they cannot receive planning permission in the villages, they have no alternative, so they claim, but to build illegally"</ref> In 1945 there were 290 illegal structures in the dispersed communities, in 1956 – 955, in 1994 – 12,000, in 1998 – 24,225, in 2004 – 42,561, and in 2011 – 64,000.<ref>Section 68 in Goldberg report</ref> Between the years 1998–2001, the demolition of illegal buildings stopped as a government policy and gradually resumed later. Law enforcement has failed, and there is no viable option to destroy all illegal construction. The threat of destruction does not deter residents from illegal building.<ref>Section 69 in Goldberg report</ref>
According to enforcement officials, it is not possible to monitor every case of illegal construction because the residents who build in the dispersed communities impose on the inspectors criminal and terrorist threats.<ref>According to the testimony of Brigadier General Menashe Arviv, head of the Coordination of enforcement activities in front of members of the [weblaw.haifa.ac.il/he/Faculty/Kedar/lecdb/general/protocol.doc committee headed by Justice Eliezer Goldberg]</ref>
According to the Commissioner of Administrative Enforcement Shlomo Cizzer: "We evacuate only intruders who have a place to live, we have evacuated, and will re-evacuate, the people who invaded [[al-Araqeeb]], because they have homes in [[Rahat]], [[Lod]], and in [[Kafr Qasim]]. They invaded just to prove ownership of the land. There are tens of thousands of others who are also criminals whom we do not evacuate, because they have no other houses to go to. Until the state decides what to do with them, we will act in accordance with the law ".<ref name="tani">Tani Goldstein, [http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3944146,00.html Is there a solution to the problem of the Negev Bedouin land?], [[Ynet]], 28 August 2010</ref>
===Ecological issues=== While Bedouin take up open spaces that could be used for touristic purposes and construction of towns to accommodate new settlers, prominent Israeli environmental figures argue, that unapproved construction of unrecognized villages are an environmental hazard.<ref>{{cite web|last=Manski|first=Rebecca|title=Bedouin Vilified Among Top 10 Environmental Hazards in Israel|url=http://www.alternativenews.org/english/index.php/aicafe/103-topics/news/825-bedouin-vilified-among-top-10-environmental-hazards-in-israel-825|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140115084009/http://www.alternativenews.org/english/index.php/aicafe/103-topics/news/825-bedouin-vilified-among-top-10-environmental-hazards-in-israel-825|dead-url=yes|archive-date=15 January 2014|publisher=AIC|accessdate=4 December 2013}}</ref>
Some ecologists say that Bedouin communities are causing damage to ecosystems since the Negev has unique habitats. There is a transitional area between the desert and the border region of the south of [[Judaean Mountains]] and [[Shfela]], where most plant and animal species perform a gradation between habitats. Therefore, this zone is vital for them, especially during the [[global warming]] when species of the desert are expected to migrate to the north.<ref name="eco">Dotan Rotem (open areas ecologist division of science from the [[Nature and Parks Authority (Israel)|Nature and Parks Authority]]), and Azri Alon (Southern District Planner in Nature and Parks Authority), The ecological effects of the Bedouin dispersals of the Negev, February 2012, Ecology and Environment Magazine</ref>
The keeping and feeding livestock bring steady amounts of vegetation food that grow wild and bring about consolidation of invading flora species. The Bedouins keep livestock in herds greater than the [[carrying capacity]] of the land, which leads to serious overgrazing, and to the creation of vast areas of empty of any plants. The cumulative effect creates huge areas where there is no vegetation at all (not natural and not agricultural) and no animals. In fact, the result is an ongoing and total destruction of habitat. Species unique to the region as ''[[Pterocles]]'', [[houbara bustard]], [[leopard fringe-fingered lizard]] and [[iris (plant)|iris]]es, disappeared from large surfaces.<ref Name="eco" />
Illegal gas stations in the Bedouin dispersed communities<ref name="dele">Gadi Golan, [http://www.israelhayom.co.il/site/newsletter_article.php?id=17957&newsletter=08.06.2012 Disaster on the way] 08/06/12, Israel Today</ref> represent a threat to the quality of air, soil and groundwater as fuel tanks do not meet basic standards of environmental protection meant to ensure that the fuel does not soak into the soil and groundwater, as well as the fuel itself does not meet environmental standards.<ref name="delek">{{cite web|url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4322005,00.html|title=ynet פונו תחנות דלק פיראטיות בישובי בדואים - כלכלה|work=ynet|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="delek2">Doron Herman and Hila Shai-Vazan, [http://news.nana10.co.il/Article/?ArticleID=806633 Illegal gas stations in the South sell fake and dangerous diesel fuel], Nana10, 08.06.2011</ref>
According to Itamar Ben Dodi from the [[Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel]], the lack of sewage infrastructure and waste removal and illegal slaughter houses in the Bedouin dispersed communities cause an accumulation and spreading of [[wastewater]] and household waste that reach streams channels and cause odor nuisances, health problems for residents, and damage to nature.<ref>According to the testimony of Itamar Ben-David, a planner from the conservation department in [[SPNI]] in front of the Goldberg committee, 13 March 2008</ref>
In July 2013 Israeli government ordered to allocate [[New Israeli Shekel|NIS]] 40 million for garbage pick-up and recycling for the Negev Bedouin communities in the area of the Al-Kasom and Neveh Midbar regional councils – for the first time. The main reason for the lack of garbage collecting services was unresolved land ownership disputes. Some homes in the area do not have legal standing and consequently do not pay local taxes which leads to the lack of income for the local authorities to operate garbage collection services.<ref>Zafrir Rinat, [http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/.premium-1.535758 Some 30,000 Bedouin to get garbage collected for first time], [[Haaretz]], 15 July 2013</ref>
A large number of Israelis, including both Bedouin and Jews, are settled in some 2.5% of the [[Negev]] desert available for civilian use living in proximity to Israel's [[nuclear reactor]]s, 22 agro and petrochemical factories, an oil terminal, closed military zones, quarries, a toxic waste incinerator ([[Ramat Hovav]]), [[cell tower]]s, a power plant, several airports, a prison, and two rivers of open sewage.<ref>BUSTAN on the Blueprint; Excerpt of [http://www.alternativenews.org/english/index.php/component/content/article/16-news-from-within/749-news-from-within-vol-xxii-no-8-october-november-2006.html Rebecca Manski, "A Desert Mirage: The Rising Role of American Money in Negev Development"]; ''News from Within,'' October/November 2005)</ref> Some of this infrastructure is concentrated on the grounds of the unrecognized village of [[wadi al-Na'am|Wadi el-Na'am]]. According to the [[Ministry of Health (Israel)|Ministry of Health]] data (as of June 2004), the rates of cancer and mortality are 65% higher for those living within a 20 km radius of the Ramat Hovav Industrial Zone. Some 350,000 people live within this danger zone, including the residents of Beer Sheva.<ref name="Am"/>
==See also== *[[Bedouin]] *[[Negev Bedouin]] *[[Negev Bedouin women]] *[[Sedentism]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Israeli administrative jurisdictions}}
==External links== * Basic information about the [http://www.mmi.gov.il/static/HanhalaPirsumim/Beduin_information.pdf Bedouin of the Negev] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ei8yHjk_MbM Lands of the Negev], film presented by [[Israel Land Administration]] describing the challenges faced in providing land management and infrastructure to the Negev Bedouin *[http://www.moch.gov.il/SiteCollectionDocuments/odot/doch_goldberg/Doch_Vaada_Shofet_Goldberg.pdf Judge Goldberg Committee Report regarding the Arrangement of the Bedouin Settlement in the Negev] {{he icon}} *[http://www.israel-al.com/content.php?id=29 Everything about the Negev Bedouin Way of Life] *[http://www.rcuv.net/ Regional Council of Unrecognized Villages], Negev Bedouin elective body *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071012170138/http://assoc40.org/index_main.html Association of Forty], NGO in the Galilee which deals with unrecognized villages throughout the country *[http://bustan.org BUSTAN] Bedouin and Jewish Negev environmental justice organization *[http://neohasid.org/negev/save_the_negev/ Save the Negev], Religious Jewish organization calling for the [[Blueprint Negev]] to respect Bedouin needs *[http://www.jnf.org/negev/ JNF website], with information on the [[Blueprint Negev]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080910014917/http://www.itemz.org/unrecognized/catalog_A4.pdf "Unrecognized" Photo Exhibition], telling the stories of community figures in the unrecognized villages, by Tal Adler
===Reports and academic articles=== *Seth Frantzman, [https://academia.edu/2267963/Presentation_to_Regavim_about_Negev Presentation to Regavim about Negev] *[http://www.pmo.gov.il/policyplanning/mimshal/Documents/goldberg.ppt The main principles of the Goldberg Committee Report] {{he icon}} *Orenstein, Daniel. [http://www.springerlink.com/content/gh7k811x54604wr7/ "Population Growth and Environmental Impact: Ideology and Academic Discourse in Israel;"] ''Population and Environment'' Volume 26, Number 1 / September 2004 *[http://www.hic-net.org/document.asp?PID=580 Habitat International Coalition: "“Unrecognized” Villages of the Naqab"] *[http://hrw.org/reports/2008/iopt0308/ Human Rights Watch: ''Off the Map – Land and Housing Rights Violations in Israel’s Unrecognized Bedouin Villages''] *[http://www.internal-displacement.org/idmc/website/countries.nsf/(httpEnvelopes)/9C7046894E560D8D802570B8005A7488?OpenDocument Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre: "Many displaced Bedouins live in settlements not recognized by the State of Israel (1999–2005)"] *[http://www.iwgia.org/sw10543.asp International Work Group for Indigenous Affairs]
===Media articles=== *Meirav Arlosoroff, [http://www.haaretz.com/news/features/settling-the-bedouin-question.premium-1.490285 Settling the Bedouin question], [[Haaretz]], 27 December 2012 *[http://www.algemeiner.com/2013/06/18/israel%E2%80%99s-negev-facing-alarming-changes Israel’s Negev Facing Alarming Changes], [[Algemeiner Journal|Algemeiner]], 18 June 2013 *[http://www.actv.co.il/portal/eportal.asp?movind=234 ACTV: Israeli documentary about government policy towards Bedouin in the Negev] {{he icon}} *[http://www.boker.org.il/english/battlesettle.htm "The Battle to settle the Negev"], ''The Jerusalem Post,'' 16 June 2005, By Yocheved Miriam Russo
{{DEFAULTSORT:Unrecognized Bedouin Villages In Israel}} [[Category:Arab citizens of Israel]] [[Category:Arab villages in Israel| ]] [[Category:Land management]] [[Category:Israeli society]] [[Category:Bedouin society]] [[Category:Bedouins in Israel]]

page.title: William B. Graham Prize for Health Services Research

revision.text:
The '''William B. Graham Prize for Health Services Research''' is an award acknowledging contributions to [[health care]] research. It is funded by the [[Baxter International]] Foundation, and awarded every year through the US-based [[Association of University Programs in Health Administration]] (AUPHA). The recipient is awarded $25,000, with another $25,000 given to a non-profit institution selected by him or her.
Until 2005, the prize was named ''The Baxter International Foundation Prize for Health Services Research''. It was renamed in 2006, after the death of long-time [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] of Baxter International, [[William B. Graham]].

{{Orphan|date=April 2018}}
'''Yusuf Khel''', along with the [[Daulat Khel]], [[Khulozai]], [[Maghdud Khel]], [[Mahmud Khel]], [[Mahsud Khel]] and [[Umar Khel]], is a sub-division of the [[Kakazai]], [[Tarkani]]s/[[Mamund]] tribe of the [[Pashtun people|Pashtuns]] located in [[Afghanistan]] and [[Pakistan]].
==References==
*''"A Dictionary of the Pathan Tribes of the North West Frontier of India"'' published by The General Staff Army Headquarter, Calcutta, India - (Originally Published 1910) :: ''Kakazai / Kakayzai'' [[Pathan]] Tribe is mentioned on Page 22 (under ‘K’ - ''[[Kakazai]]''), Page 12 (under ‘D’ - ''[[Daulat Khel]]'' - A sub-division of [[Kakazai]] [[Pathans]]), Page 26 (under 'K' - ''[[Khulozai]]'' - A sub-division of [[Kakazai]] [[Pathans]]), Page 29 (under ‘M’ - ''[[Maghdud Khel]]'', ''[[Mahsud Khel]]'' and ''[[Mahmud Khel]]'' - sub-divisions of [[Kakazai]] [[Pathans]]), Page 47 (under 'U' - ''Umar Khel'' - A sub-division of [[Kakazai]] [[Pathans]]) and Page 50 (under 'Y' - ''Yusuf Khel'' - A sub-division of [[Kakazai]] [[Pathans]])
